0.text: Holofernes and Nathaniel discuss Don Armado, with whom Nathaniel has been conversing. They mock his inferior intellect, criticizing his pronunciation and saying that they abhor 'such rackers of orthography' . Armado, Moth, and Costard enter; Armado tells the learned men that the King has asked him to prepare 'some delightful ostentation, or show, or pageant, or antick or firework'  to entertain the Princess and her party. He asks Holofernes and Nathaniel for their help in planning this entertainment, and Holofernes suggests that they present a show of the Nine Worthies. The men discuss who will play the roles of the Worthies, with Holofernes saying that he will play three of the roles himself. They then go off to plan their show.

2.text:
Holofernes and Nathaniel discuss Don Armado, with whom Nathaniel has spoken. They mock his inferior intelligence, criticizing his language use and declaring that they 'hate such disorderly writers.' Armado, Moth, and Costard enter; Armado tells the scholars that the King has asked for a 'pleasant pastime, or show, or spectacle, or interlude' to be organized for the Princess and her retinue. He asks Holofernes and Nathaniel for help in planning this pastime, and Holofernes suggests they create a piece based on the Nine Worthies. They discuss which roles the Worthies will play, with Holofernes stating that he himself will take on three roles. They leave to plan their piece.

Translation:

Holofernes en Nathaniel praten over Don Armado, met wie Nathaniel gesproken heeft. Ze spotten zijn ondergeschikte intelligentie aan, kritiserend zijn taalgebruik en bevestigden dat ze 'zulke ongeordende schrijvers' haaten. Armado, Moth en Costard binnentreden; Armado vertelt de geleerden dat de Koning een 'aangenaam vermaak, of show, of spektakel, of interlude' heeft gevraagd om voor de Prinses en haar gevolg te organiseren. Hij vraagt Holofernes en Nathaniel om hun hulp bij het planning van dit vermaak, en Holofernes voorschlagt dat ze een stukje maken gebaseerd op de Negen Edelen. Ze bespreken dan welke rollen de Edelen zullen spelen, waarbij Holofernes zegt dat hij zelf drie rollen zal opnemen. Ze vertrekken om hun stuk te planningen.

0.text: Jim and the Harling children feel the happiest and most content that spring just playing in the garden. They do not yet know that the summer will change everything. In the beginning of summer, some Italians come into town and set up a dancing pavilion in a vacant lot. They begin giving dancing lessons to children, and people start to gather and congregate around the lot. Now there is something for people to do and somewhere for them to socialize. Dancing becomes a city-wide craze, and every Saturday night there is a late-night dance. Jim goes all the time, as do many girls and boys from the country. At this point, Antonia, Lena, and Tiny become known as 'the hired girls' and are always at the dances too.

2.text: At the beginning of spring, Jim and the Harlingchildren feel happiest and most contented while just playing in the garden. They don't know yet that summer brings changes. At the beginning of summer, Italians come to the city and set up a dance pavilion on an empty lot. They start teaching children to dance, and people begin to gather and collect around the lot. There's something for people to do and a place for them to meet. Dancing becomes a city-wide craze, and every Saturday night there's a late-night dance. Jim goes every time, just like many girls and boys from the area. At this moment, Antonia, Lena, and Tiny are recognized as 'the hired girls' and are always present at the dances. (Note: 'hired girls' is the English equivalent of 'gehuurde meisjes')

0.text: Elizabeth reads through Darcy's letter with a mixture of emotions. When she first reads Darcy's explanation of his conduct with Bingley and Jane, she dismisses his explanation of his concern about Jane's indifference as false, and believes he acted solely because of her family. However, when she begins reading his explanation of the dealings with Wickham, she begins to read more clearly. She soon begins to realize that she had not known anything of Wickham before the night when he told her of he and Darcy, and she wonders why she didn't realize his impropriety at speaking of such things to a stranger. As she continues to reread and think, she realizes that she had been 'blind, partial, prejudiced, absurd,' and that she believes Darcy's version of what happened. She then rereads the section about Jane and Bingley, and sees that she cannot deny the justice of his description of Jane's seeming indifference after all. After two hours of wandering in the park she returns home to be told that both Fitzwilliam and Darcy had come to say their good-byes

2.text: Elizabeth Bennet's face bore a mixture of emotions. When she first read his explanation of his behavior towards Bingley and Jane, she refused to believe his account of her indifference was false and thought he had only acted out of fear for his family. But when she began to read about his dealings with Wickham, she became clearer in her understanding. She realized she knew nothing about Wickham before Darcy had told her about their conversation, and she wondered why she had not noticed his inappropriate behavior towards an unknown woman. As she continued to read and ponder, she came to the conclusion that she was 'blind, partial, prejudiced, absurd.' She now believed Darcy's version of the events. She reread the passage about Jane and Bingley and could not deny the justice in his description of her seeming indifference. After two hours of walking in the park, she returned home to find out that Fitzwilliam and Darcy had already departed to bid their farewells.

4.text:
In English:

The expression on Elizabeth Bennet's face showed a mixture of emotions. The first time she read his declaration about his behavior towards Bingley and Jane, she refused to believe his version of her indifference and thought he had only acted out of fear for his family. But when she read about his connections to Wickham, she gained clearer insights. She realized she knew nothing about Wickham before Darcy told her, and she wondered why she hadn't noticed his inappropriate behavior towards an unknown woman. As she continued to read and ponder, she came to the conclusion that she was 'blind, partial, prejudiced, and self-deceiving.' She now believed Darcy's account of the events. She reread the passage about Jane and Bingley and could not deny his justice. After two hours of walking in the park, she returned home to find Fitzwilliam and Darcy had already left to take their leave.

Zij keerde terug naar het gedeelte over Jane en Bingley en kon zijn verdediging niet langer ontkennen. Na twee uur wandelen in het park keerde zij thuis en ontdekte dat Fitzwilliam en Darcy al waren vertrokken.

She realized that she knew nothing about Wickham before Darcy disclosed it, and she pondered why she had not noticed his inappropriate behavior towards an unknown woman. Deep in thought and completely absorbed in her book, she came to the conclusion that she was 'blind, narrow-minded, unjust, and self-centered.' She endorsed Darcy's version of events. After two hours of walking in the park, she returned home and found Fitzwilliam and Darcy missing.

0.text: Cunegonde tells her story to Candide: Bulgar soldiers attack and kill her family and rape her. While Cunegonde fights off her attacker, a captain comes in and, enraged at the officer's disrespect, kills him. He then takes Cunegonde as a prisoner of war. The captain keeps Cunegonde as his servant for three months and then sells her to a Jewish businessman. The businessman shares her services with the same Inquisitor who ordered the execution of Pangloss and flogging of Candide. Cunegonde wards off the sexual advances of both men. Cunegonde attends the post-earthquake execution and recognizes Candide. Cunegonde's story ends. Back in the present, Candide and Cunegonde eat dinner together and hang out until one of her owners, the businessman Don Issachar, comes to get her.

2.text:
Cunegonde tells Candide: Bulgarian soldiers attack and kill her family and rape her. While Cunegonde resists her attacker, a captain intervenes and, seeing the inappropriate behavior of the officer, angrily kills him. Then he takes Cunegonde captive as a war prize. The captain keeps Cunegonde as a servant for three months and eventually sells her to a Jewish merchant. The merchant makes her services available to the same Inquisitor, who had given the order to inflict painful punishments on Pangloss and Candide. Cunegonde manages to defend herself against the sexual advances of both men. The story of Cunegonde ends here. Later, Candide and Cunegonde eat together and live together until one of her owners, the merchant Don Issachar, comes to claim her.

0.text: Jane and Rochester have a quiet wedding three days after that. Diana and Mary are happy for her and say they will come to visit. St. John did not reply to the letter Jane sent to him regarding the wedding; however, he has since maintained a correspondence with her. Jane goes to see Adele and changes her school for a better and closer one. Jane then tells the reader that it has been ten years now that she has been married as she sits to write about her life. She and Rochester are always together, and after two years, he had regained sight in one of his eyes, enough to see his first-born son. Diana and Mary are both married and come to visit Jane, and she visits them. St. John went to India and is still there. He remained unmarried, and Jane relates that he feels that he will soon die and join God

0.text: Falstaff and Bardolph appear on a public road near Coventry, followed by a newly enlisted company of soldiers. Sir John orders Bardolph to replenish his supply of sack and to tell Peto to meet him at the town's end. He dislikes the idea of marching his men through the town in their rags and tatters. Abjectly impoverished, not one of them could pay him, as so many others had, for release from military service. In Falstaff's own words, 'No eye hath seen such scarecrows' . Prince Hal and Westmoreland meet him on the road and comment on the poor creatures whom Falstaff leads. The knight remains undisturbed and is philosophical in the face of this criticism. And, for that matter, the prince seems amused rather than indignant. All are to make haste, says Hal, for Percy is already in the field.

2.text:
Falstaff and Bardolph appeared on Coventry's marketplace, followed by a newly recruited company of soldiers. Sir John orders Bardolf to fill his pouch with supplies and tells Peto to report to him at the end of the town. He has no inclination to let his men march through the town in their outdated and ragged clothing. Not a single one of them could pay him, just like many others, except for those conscripted. According to Falstaff's own words: 'No eye has ever seen such a motley crew.'

Prince Hal and Westmoreland encounter him on the road and comment on the unsightly beings Falstaff leads. Falstaff remains unfazed and philosophizes in the face of this criticism. In fact, the prince even laughs at him unperturbed. 'We must hurry,' says Hal, 'for Percy is already on the field.'

(Note: In this translation, I have tried to preserve the original meaning and context of the passage as much as possible while translating from Dutch to English. The translation is intended to be as faithful as possible to the original text.)

Falstaff and Bardolph made their appearance on Coventry's market square, accompanied by a newly enlisted troop of soldiers. Sir John instructs Bardolf to fill his pouch with provisions and bids Peto to join him at the town's end. He has no intention of letting his men parade through the town in their outdated and shabby attire. None of them could pay him, not even a single one, except for those conscripted. According to Falstaff's own account: 'No eye has ever beheld such a motley crew.'

Prince Hal and Westmoreland cross paths with him on the road and remark upon the pitiful creatures Falstaff commands. Falstaff remains unruffled and ponders in the face of this criticism. In truth, the prince even chuckles at him unconcernedly. 'We must be on our way,' Hal says, 'for Percy is already on the battlefield.'

4.text:
Falstaff and Bardolph appeared on Coventry's market square, accompanied by a new recruited troop of soldiers. Sir John ordered Bardolf to fill his pockets with supplies and invited Peto to join him at the end of the town. He had no intention of letting his men march through the town in their outdated and rundown clothing. Not a single one of them could pay, not even one, unless they had been recruited. According to Falstaff's own words: 'No eye has ever seen such a motley crew.'

Prince Hal and Westmoreland came upon him and commented on the unpleasant aura of the beings that Falstaff was leading. Falstaff remained unfazed and philosophized in the face of this criticism. In reality, Hal laughed unperturbed at him. 'We must be quick,' Hal said, 'for Percy is already on the battlefield.'

(Note: In this translation, I have tried to preserve as much of the original meaning and context as possible while translating from Dutch to English. The translation is intended to closely match the original.)

According to Falstaff's own words: 'No eye has ever seen such a motley crew.'

Prince Hal and Westmoreland came across him and made comments about the unpleasant aura of the beings that Falstaff was leading. Falstaff remained unruffled and philosophized in the face of this criticism. In reality, Hal laughed unperturbed at him. 'We must be quick,' Hal said, 'for Percy is already on the battlefield.'

6.text:
Falstad and Bardolph appeared on Coventry's marketplace, accompanied by a newly recruited troop of soldiers. Sir John ordered Bardolph to fill his bags with supplies and invited Peto to join him at the end of the line. He didn't intend for his men to march through the city in their outdated and tattered clothing. Not a single one of them could pay, not one, unless they were enlisted. According to Falstaff's own words: 'No eye has ever seen such a motley crew.'

Prince Hal and Westmoreland encountered him and made comments about the unpleasant smelling creatures that Falstaff led. Falstaff remained unperturbed and philosophized in the face of this criticism. In reality, Hal unperturbedly laughed at him. 'We must be quick,' Hal said, 'for Percy is already on the battlefield.'

8.text:
Falstaff and Bardolph appeared on Coventry's market square, accompanied by a new recruited troop of soldiers. Falstaff ordered Bardolph to fill his pockets with supplies and invited Peto to join him in the ranks. He didn't intend for his men to march through the city in their outdated and worn clothing. Not a single one of them could pay, none at all, unless they had enlisted. According to Falstaff's own words: 'No eye has ever seen such a motley crew.'

Prince Hal and Westmoreland encountered him and made comments about the unpleasantly smelling creatures that Falstaff led. Falstaff remained unfazed and philosophized about their criticism. In reality, Hal remained calm and unperturbed, laughing silently at him. 'We must hurry,' Hal said, 'for Percy is already on the battlefield.'

10.text:
Falstaff and Bardolph appeared on Coventry's market square, accompanied by a newly recruited troop of soldiers. Falstaff ordered Bardolph to fill his bags with supplies and invited Peto to join them. He didn't intend for his men to parade through the city in their outdated and worn-out clothing. Not a single one of them could pay, unless they were enlisted. According to Falstaff's own words: 'No eye has ever seen such a motley crew.'

Prince Hal and Westmoreland encountered him and made comments about the unpleasant-smelling creatures that Falstaff was leading. Falstaff remained unperturbed and philosophized about their criticism. In reality, Hal remained calm and uneasy, with a quiet smirk on his face. 'We must be quick,' Hal said, 'for Percy is already on the battlefield.'

13.text:
'Falstaff and Bardolph appeared on Coventry's marketplace, accompanied by a newly recruited troop of soldiers. Falstaff ordered Bardolph to fill his pouches with food and invited Peto to join them. He didn't want his men to be seen in the city in their old and tattered clothing. No one could pay unless they were enlisted. According to Falstaff himself: 'We have never seen such a motley crew.'

Prince Hal and Westmoreland encountered him and made comments about the unpleasant smelling creatures that Falstaff brought along. Falstaff took their remarks in stride and pondered over their observations. In reality, Hal remained calm and surprised, still with a pipe in his mouth. 'We must go quickly,' Hal said, 'for Percy is already on the battlefield.' (Note: Percy = Hotspur)

Translation:
Falstaff and Bardolph appeared on Coventry's marketplace, accompanied by a newly recruited troop of soldiers. Falstaff ordered Bardolph to fill his pouches with food and invited Peto to join them. He didn't want his men to be seen in the city in their old and tattered clothing. No one could pay unless they were enlisted. According to Falstaff himself: 'We have never seen such a motley crew.'

Prince Hal and Westmoreland came across him and made comments about the unpleasant-smelling creatures that accompanied Falstaff. Falstaff took their remarks in stride and pondered over their observations. In reality, Hal remained calm and surprised, still with a pipe in his mouth. 'We had better go quickly,' Hal said, 'for Percy is already on the battlefield.'

0.text: Now that he has felt the pain of losing his son, Siddhartha has more sympathy with the needs and desires of ordinary people. He again decides to seek his son in the town, but stops when he thinks he hears a special message from the river. He remembers when he rebelled against his own father, and realizes that his father must have suffered the same pain as he, Siddhartha, suffers now. Sorrows repeat themselves. Still suffering, he returns to the hut and tells Vasudeva of his troubles. Vasudeva, in his silent attentiveness, seems to Siddhartha like a god. They both go and sit by the river bank. Siddhartha practices his technique of listening to the river and realizes the unity of all life amidst all its diverse elements. He realizes that in the unity is perfection. His pain disappears as his Self merges with the unity. From that moment on, Siddhartha no longer fights against his destiny. He accepts everything. Vasudeva, now that he has seen his friend attain enlightenment, announces that he is leaving. He is going to live in the woods and be in the unity of all things.

2.text:
After losing his son, Siddhartha gained a deeper understanding of the needs and desires of common people. He decided to search for his son again in the city, but stopped when he thought he would hear a special message from the river. He remembered his resistance towards his own father and realized that his father probably suffered the same pain as he, Siddhartha, did now. Regret returned. Still suffering, he went back to his hut and told Vasudeva about his problems. Vasudeva, in his calm observation, seemed to Siddhartha like a god. They sat together by the river. Siddhartha practiced his technique of listening to the river and realized the unity of all in life, with all its diversities. In unity lies perfection. His pain disappeared when his Self merged with the unity. From that moment, Siddhartha accepted his destiny. He accepted everything. Vasudeva, after helping his friend to enlightenment, decided to leave. He went to live in the forest and led his existence in the unity of all.

Translation:

Na de dood van zijn zoon had Siddhartha een diepere inzicht in de behoeften en wensen van de gewone mensen. Hij besloot zijn zoon opnieuw te zoeken in de stad, maar stopte daarop toen hij dacht dat hij een speciale boodschap van de rivier zou horen. Hij herinnerde zich zijn weerstand tegen zijn eigen vader en realiseerde zich dat zijn vader waarschijnlijk dezelfde pijn leed als hij, Siddhartha, nu ervoerde. Terugkeer van het regret. Nog steeds lijdend keerde hij terug naar zijn hut en vertelde Vasudeva over zijn problemen. Vasudeva, in zijn rustige observatie, leek Siddhartha als een god. Ze zaten samen aan de oever van de rivier. Siddhartha oefende zijn techniek van luisteren naar de rivier en realiseerde de eenheid van alles in het leven, met alle zijn diversiteiten. In eenheid zit volmaaktheid. Zijn pijn verdween toen zijn Zelf met de eenheid versmolten. Vanaf dat

0.text: Salisbury, Pembroke, and Lord Bigot come onstage. The battle is still raging. The dudes can't believe that King John's forces are still standing strong. That said, they thinks it's awesome that King John had to leave the battle with a doctor's note. Just then, in comes the French Count Melun, who's trying to hold his guts so they don't fall out of his body. Melun tells the English lords to abandon their rebellion and swear allegiance to King John once more, because if the French and the rebels defeat King John, Louis the Dauphin plans to have all his English allies beheaded. At first, Salisbury can't believe him. But then Melun explains that he is about to die, anyway, and he'll get a better reward in heaven by telling the truth now than by keeping mum. Anyway, he explains, his grandfather was English, so he has some sympathy for them. Salisbury definitely doesn't want to get his head lopped off, so he decides to believe Melun. Salisbury and the other English nobles leave the stage, taking Melun with them.

2.text:
Salisbury, Pembroke and Lord Bigot appear. The battle continues. The lords are astonished to discover that King John's troops are still stuck in their saddles. But they are delighted that King John was forced to retreat with a doctor's letter. Suddenly, the French Count Melun bursts in, choking from pain in his stomach. Melun calls on the English lords to put down their rebellion and swear allegiance to King John again, for the French and the rebels have defeated King John, and Louis the Dauphin plans to chop off the heads of all English allies. At first, Salisbury finds this hard to believe. But then Melun explains that he will soon be dead and sicker in the afterlife if he lies, and that he has a familial bond with them as his grandfather was English. Salisbury is determined not to lose his head, so he decides to believe Melun. Salisbury and the English lords depart with Melun.

Translation:

Salisbury, Pembroke and Lord Bigot make their appearance. The battle rages on. The lords are surprised to find that King John's troops are still stuck in their saddles. But they are pleased that King John had to retreat with a doctor's letter. Suddenly, the French Count Melun bursts in, near death from stomach pain. Melun urges the English lords to put down their rebellion and swear allegiance to King John once more, for the French and the rebels have overpowered King John, and Louis the Dauphin plans to behead all English allies. Initially, Salisbury finds this hard to accept. But then Melun reveals that he will suffer more in the afterlife for lying than for remaining silent, and that he shares a familial bond with them, as his grandfather was English. Salisbury is resolute not to lose his head, so he decides to believe Melun. Salisbury and the English lords depart with Melun.

4.text: Salisbury, Pembroke and Lord Bigot appear. The fight continues. The lords are astonished to discover that King John's troops are still stuck in their saddles. 0.text: There is much speculation at the training college when Sue does not return that evening at prayer time. Everyone wonders about the young man she has gone out with, and some of them are convinced that Jude is only posing as her cousin. The situation takes a serious turn because a similar incident occurred the year before: a young man had managed to seduce a student of the same college, maintaining that he was her cousin. The mistress inquires about the two photographs on Sue's dressing table. One is of Mr. Phillotson, and the other is of an unknown undergraduate. The next morning, when Sue does return, she is punished and kept in solitary confinement. The other students feel the punishment is too harsh and prepare to protest. In the evening it is discovered that Sue has escaped from a back window. She turns up at Jude's place. She is soaked and shivering with cold. Jude immediately takes her in and offers her some dry clothes and brandy. Sue is so tired that she falls asleep while relating her story.

2.text: In the application process for her education, rumors arose when Sue failed to return that evening for prayers. Everyone was surprised by the young man she had gone out with, and some thought Jude was only pretending to be her uncle. The situation heated up when it was discovered that for the second year in a row, a male student from the same school had been seduced, posing as her uncle. The director began to wonder about the two photos of Sue on her desk. One was of Mr. Phillotson, the other of an unknown student. The next morning, when Sue returned, she was punished and placed in isolation. The other students felt the punishment was too harsh and prepared to protest. That evening, it was discovered that Sue had escaped through a window. She went to Jude's place, wet and frightened. Jude offered her dry clothes and brandy. Sue was so exhausted that she fell asleep while telling her story.

The director began to doubt the two photos of Sue on her desk. One was of Mr. Phillotson, the other of an unknown student. The next morning, when Sue returned, she was punished and placed in isolation. The other students felt that the punishment was too harsh and prepared to protest. That evening, it was discovered that Sue had escaped through a window. She went to Jude, wet and frightened. Jude offered her dry clothes and brandy. Sue was so exhausted that she fell asleep during the telling of her story.

Tom agrees to take Gloucester to the cliff.

0.text: The next morning Mr. Gardiner starts off for London when no letter from Mr. Bennet arrives. Mrs. Gardiner and the children decide to stay in Longbourn for a few days to try to help, and on Tuesday she receives a letter from her husband saying that he and Mr. Bennet are searching the hotels in town for Lydia and Wickham. A letter soon arrives from Mr. Collins saying that he has heard of their misfortune, and writing Mr. Bennet that it would be best for him to 'throw off your unworthy child from your affections for ever. Mr. Gardiner writes again saying he has no news yet other than that Wickham does not seem to have any family or friends that they could be staying with, and that he left a number of gambling debts in Brighton. Mr. Bennet returns home, and Mrs. Gardiner and her children leave. Mr. Bennet tells Elizabeth that she was justified in her advice to him before Lydia left, and that he has learnt to be cautious about his daughters

2.text: The next morning, Mr. Gardiner departs for London as no letter from Mr. Bennet has been received. Mrs. Gardiner and the children decide to stay a few more days in Longbourn to help. On Tuesday, they receive a letter from Mr. Gardiner's husband, stating that he and Mr. Bennet are searching for Lydia and Wickham in the city's hotels. A letter arrives swiftly from Mr. Collins, who has been informed of their misfortune. Mr. Bennet writes that it would be best to disown his disgraceful daughter forever. Mr. Gardiner writes again that they have not found any family or friends of Wickham where they can be located, and that he left some gambling debts behind in Brighton. Mr. Bennet returns home, and Mrs. Gardiner and her children depart. Mr. Bennet tells Elizabeth that she was right in her counsel to him before Lydia left.

4.text:
The following morning, Meneer Gardiner travels to London because no letter from Meneer Bennet has been received. Mevrouw Gardiner and their children decide to stay a few more days in Longbourn to help. On Tuesday, they receive a letter from Meneer Gardiner's wife, in which he mentions that he and Meneer Bennet are searching for Lydia and Wickham in the city hotels. A letter from Meneer Collins arrives soon, who has already heard of their misfortune. Meneer Bennet writes that it is best to completely disown Lydia if she disgraces herself. Meneer Gardiner writes again that they cannot find any family or friends of Wickham where they are, and that he left debts in Brighton. Meneer Bennet returns home, and Mevrouw Gardiner and her children leave. Meneer Bennet tells Elizabeth that she was right in her advice to him before Lydia left.

Translation:

De volgende morgen reist Meneer Gardiner naar London omdat er geen brief van Meneer Bennet ontvangen is. Mevrouw Gardiner en hun kinderen besluiten enkele dagen langer in Longbourn te blijven om te helpen. Op dinsdag ontvangen ze een brief van het echtgenoot van Meneer Gardiner, waarin hij melding maakt dat hij en Meneer Bennet in de stadshotels zoeken naar Lydia en Wickham. Er komt snel een brief van Meneer Collins, die reeds van hun ramp gehoord heeft. Meneer Bennet schrijft dat het beste is Lydia helemaal af te wijzen als zij zich schandeert. Meneer Gardiner schrijft opnieuw dat ze geen familie of vrienden van Wickham kunnen vinden waar ze te vinden zijn, en dat hij achter schulden achtergelaten heeft in Brighton. Meneer Bennet keert terug thuis, en Mevrouw Gardiner en haar kinderen vertrekken. Meneer Bennet vertelt Elizabeth dat zij gelijk had in haar raadgeving aan hem voordat Lydia wegging.

0.text: Scrooge wakes up in his bedroom and joyfully repeats his vow to live from the lessons of the three ghosts. He runs around his house and then outside, where church bells ring. A boy tells him it is Christmas Day, and Scrooge realizes that the ghosts visited him all in one night. Scrooge buys a prize turkey and sends it to Bob Cratchit's house. Scrooge dresses in his best clothing and walks in the crowds with a smile. He gives a great deal of money to the portly gentleman who had asked him for a charitable donation yesterday. Scrooge continues to walk through the city and happily talks with everyone he meets. He visits Fred's house and has a wonderful time at the party. The next morning, Scrooge gets to work early. When Cratchit comes in late, Scrooge pretends to reprimand him, then gives him a raise. Scrooge continues his kindly ways, befriending everyone and becoming a second father to Tiny Tim, who does not die. He never sees the ghosts again, but he keeps the spirit of Christmas alive in his heart as well as anyone.

0.text: Sara may be a weird kid, but Ermengarde St. John has a decidedly weird name. She's not super smart, poor thing, and is blown away by Sara's ability to learn French. Miss Minchin isn't very nice to Ermengarde, and because of this, Sara feels the need to reach out to her. After lessons, Sara introduces herself. Ermengarde goes on about how clever Sara must be because she can speak French. Sara does what any child would upon making a friend --she asks Ermengarde if she'd like to meet Emily, her doll. When she starts to tell fantastical stories about Emily, Ermengarde is amazed at how she's able to just make things up on the fly. Suddenly, Sara looks like she's in pain. Ermengarde asks her what is up with that, and Sara responds that she's in pain because she misses her father. Then, Ermengarde asks Sara if she'd like to be her best friend. Which is not weird at all. Sara agrees. Yay, BFF!

100.text:
Two days later, Mr. Micawber accompanies Mrs. Betsey during a hospital visit and a funeral. She tells him that her husband had passed away and posed no threat to her anymore. Before she departs for Australia, Mr. Micawber takes charge of Mrs. Betsey's affairs. He sets to work. Mrs. Betsey's objections against her familial ties upon her departure are considered by Mr. Micawber. Mr. Micawber, Traddles, Mrs. Betsey, and Agnes discuss the Micawbers' financial situation. Traddles proposes a plan to recover Mrs. Betsey and Mr. Wickfield's money. Agnes reveals that she has rented a house and started a school to secure her and her father's financial safety. During David's journey, news of Uriah's murder spreads, and his mother is the prime suspect.

(English to Dutch translation:)

Twee dagen later begeleidt Mr. Micawber Mrs. Betsey tijdens een ziekenhuisbezoek en bij een begrafenis. Zij vertelt hem dat haar man was overleden en geen bedreiging meer was voor haar. Voordat zij naar Australi vertrekt, neemt Mr. Micawber de zaken van Mrs. Betsey over. Hij gaat aan de slag. De bezwaren van Mrs. Betsey tegen haar familiale banden bij haar vertrek worden door Mr. Micawber overwogen. Mr. Micawber, Traddles, Mrs. Betsey en Agnes praten over de financile situatie van de Micawbers. Traddles voordracht een plan om het geld van Mrs. Betsey en Mr. Wickfield terug te krijgen. Agnes onthult dat zij een huis heeft verhuurd en een school heeft gestart om haar en haar vader financieel veilig te stellen. Tijdens de reis van David verspreidt het nieuws over de moord op Uriah zich, en zijn moeder is de hoofdverdachte.

0.text: We begin with a prologue. An actor dressed in armor comes out on stage and welcomes us to ancient Troy, where the Greeks and Trojans have been going at it on the Trojan battlefields for the last...get this...7 years. Since we're starting out 'in the middle' of all the action, the Prologue quickly catches us up to speed. You know, just in case we've never heard of a little old thing called the Trojan War. Here are the deets: the Greeks have sailed across the 'Athenian Bay' to 'ransack' Troy because a Trojan Prince named Paris stole Helen from the Greek King Menelaus and has been sleeping with her ever since. Simple as that. Next, the Prologue warns us that we might not like the play because nothing good ever really happens in times of 'war.' By the way, Shmooperinos, the Prologue says absolutely NOTHING about Troilus and Cressida, the two characters Shakespeare named this play after. What's up with that?

2.text: We commence with a prologue. An actor in armor strides onto the stage and indicates ancient Troy, where Greeks and Trojans have clashed for seven long years on the battlefields of Troy. Given that we are now 'in the thick of it,' the Prologue swiftly informs us: you are likely unfamiliar with an ancient tale named the Trojan War. Here's a synopsis: the Greeks voyaged across the 'Aegean Sea' to loot Troy due to a Trojan Prince named Paris, who had abducted Menelaus, the Greek King's wife, Helen, and continued living with her. This much is clear. The Prologue also cautions us that we might not relish the play as during 'wartime,' nothing truly good transpires. Remarkably, the Prologue mentions nothing about Troilus and Cressida, the characters after whom Shakespeare titled this play. What's the joke there?

4.text:
We begin with a prologue. An actor in armor steps onto the stage and indicates ancient Troy, where Greeks and Trojans have fiercely fought on the battlefields of Troy. Since we are right in the midst of the fight, the Prologue quickly explains: you are probably unfamiliar with an old story called the Trojan War. Here's a summary: the Greeks sailed over the 'Aegean Sea' to plunder Troy because a Trojan Prince named Paris had stolen Helen, the wife of the Greek King, Menelaus, and lived with her. That much is clear. The Prologue also warns us that we are unlikely to enjoy the performance much, as 'during the war' not much good happens. Interestingly, the Prologue avoids any mention of Troilus and Cressida, the characters after whom Shakespeare named the play. What's the joke there?

0.text: Venn calls on Eustacia, but she cannot be persuaded to give up Wildeve, despite his telling her that he has seen and overheard them at Rainbarrow. Venn goes to Mrs. Yeobright and asks for her niece's hand in marriage, informing her that though he himself has proposed to Thomasin and been rejected, things are different now. Mrs. Yeobright rejects his offer. Mrs. Yeobright meets Wildeve and lets him know that he is not her niece's only suitor. Wildeve is still unwilling to commit himself and rushes to meet Eustacia to ask her if she will commit herself to him, but she refuses to do so. Back at home, Captain Vye mentions that Clym Yeobright is returning home from Paris at Christmas.

2.text:
Venn summons Eustacia but she refuses to be persuaded by Wildve, regardless of his assurance that he saw and heard her at Rainbarrow. Venn visits Mrs. Yeobright and asks for her consent for his sister to marry, revealing that he himself was asked and refused by Thomasin, but that the situation has changed. Mrs. Yeobright refuses his proposal. Mrs. Yeobright encounters Wildve and tells him that he has no exclusive relationship with Eustacia. Wildve remains unwilling to marry and rushes to her to ask if she will bind herself to him, but she refuses. At home, Captain Vye informs that Clym Yeobright is coming back from Paris for Christmas.

[Translation:]
Venn calls for Eustacia, yet she refuses to be convinced by Wildve, disregarding his assurance that he had seen and heard her at Rainbarrow. Venn goes to see Mrs. Yeobright and asks for her permission for his sister to wed, disclosing that he himself had been asked and declined by Thomasin, but that the circumstances have shifted. Fitzwilliam tells her that recently Darcy has saved a friend from an unwise marriage, and he suspects this friend to be Bingley. Elizabeth is pained over hearing the news. 0.text: Hamilton defends the treaty-making procedures outlined in the Constitution. He responds to the criticism that the Constitution wrongly mixes the legislative and executive branches of government by affording both a role in making and approving treaties. Hamilton argues that act of treaty-making does not fit neatly into the typical purview of either the executive or legislative branch. Therefore, affording a role to both is appropriate. Other critics claimed that the power to make treaties should be limited to the president. Hamilton responds that, unlike European monarchs, the president is only in office for a limited period of time. He may therefore be tempted to sign a treaty detrimental to the nation but beneficial to his private interests since he will eventually return to being a private citizen . It is therefore necessary that his power be held in check by the legislature. Others asserted that the Congress should have even greater authority over treaty making. However, Hamilton responds that this would introduce unnecessary delays and inefficiencies to the process and weaken the American negotiating position.

2.text:
Here is the English translation of the Dutch text:

Hamilton defends the treaty-making procedures as described in the Constitution. He responds to the criticism that the Constitution incorrectly assigns both legislative and executive roles in treaty-making. Hamilton argues that treaty-making does not fit neatly into the usual sphere of either the executive or legislative branches. Therefore, it is fitting for both to have a role. Other critics argue that the power to make treaties should only be vested in the president. However, Hamilton counters that, unlike European monarchs, the president serves for a limited term. He may therefore be inclined to conclude a treaty that is detrimental to the nation but beneficial to his personal interests, as he ultimately returns as a private citizen. Hence, it is necessary to keep his power in check by the legislative branch. Additionally, some argue that Congress should have even more power over treaties. However, Hamilton maintains that this would introduce unnecessary delays and inefficiencies in the process, weakening the American negotiating position.

0.text: Linda and Mrs. Bruce go off on vacation, and Linda experiences plenty of ugly prejudice, even though she's working as a nurse for Mrs. Bruce's child. Like: The waiters won't give her tea when she's eating with Mrs. Bruce. She's not allowed to sit in a chair and hold the child on her lap, but has to place the child in the chair and stand behind her. The servants won't bring her dinner to her room when Mrs. Bruce asks them to, so she has to go down to the kitchen to get it herself. Finally, Linda puts her foot down and says that Mrs. Bruce is paying for her just like any of the white servants, so she'd better be treated like one of them. This actually works. See, Linda says, you've just got to stand up for your rights.

0.text: After Leon had gone, Emma began a period of secret mourning. She drifted about aimlessly and was often melancholy. She saw Leon in her imagination as the hero of all her dreams and remembered their walks and conversations. She reproached herself for not having responded to his love, and he became the center of all her thoughts. In her misery, she began again the strange and unpredictable behavior that had marked her in Tostes. Her moods constantly changed, and she was often giddy and nervous. One day Rodolphe Boulanger, a handsome and wealthy landowner, brought one of his servants to be treated by Bovary. While there he saw Emma and was immediately attracted by her good looks and ladylike bearing. Boulanger was a suave bachelor, both coarse and shrewd. At once his thoughts turned to Emma's seduction, and he began to lay his plans.

In an instant, his thoughts turned to Emma's temptation, and he began to formulate his plans.

0.text: Jane befriends Diana and Mary, who admire her drawings and give her books to read. St. John, on the other hand, remains distant and cold, although he is never unkind. After a month, Diana and Mary must return to their posts as governesses. St. John has found a position for Jane, running a charity school for girls in the town of Morton. Jane accepts, but St. John presumes that she will soon leave the school out of restlessness, perhaps because he himself is quite restless. His sisters suspect he will soon leave England for a missionary post overseas. St. John tells his sisters that their Uncle John has died and left them nothing, because all his money went to another, unknown, relative. Jane learns that it was Uncle John who led Mr. Rivers into his disastrous business deal

0.text: Alek and his companions are at the Swiss border in their walker, but a German land frigate is waiting for them. Uh-oh... They decide the only way to get past it is to try to sneak by at night--because everyone thinks piloting a walker at night is too dangerous. The land frigate sends out searchlights at random intervals, which they have to sneak by. They try disguising the walker's noise by walking in a loud streambed. Pretty smart thinking. They run right into some German soldiers on foot, but the walker manages to plow through them. Alek speeds up, taking the walker into a run--at night.

2.text: Alek and his companions are seated in their military walker at the Swiss-German border, but there is a German patrol boat on alert. They are agitated... They decide that the only way to bypass it is to try and pass through at night--as everyone finds operating a walker at night dangerous. The patrol boat turns on intermittent searchlights that they must avoid. They try to hide the sounds of the walker by passing through a rough creek bed. That's quite cunning of them. They encounter German foot soldiers, but the walker rumbles through them. Alek speeds up, pushes the military walker into a sprint--at night.

4.text: Alek and his companions sit in their military walker at the Swiss-German border, but a German patrol boat is on high alert. They feel uneasy... They decide that the only way to bypass it is to do it at night--because everyone finds it dangerous to operate a night military walker. The patrol boat sets intermittent spotlights, which they have to avoid. They try to hide the sounds of the military walker by making it drive through a rough riverbed. That's quite clever of them. They encounter German infantrymen, but the military walker drives through them. Alek accelerates, pushes the military walker into a sprint--at night.

De patrouilleboot voelt zich ongemakkelijk met de zwarte lichten die ze ontmoet. Ze ontmoeten Duitse infanteristen, maar hun militair voertuig hengt hen aan. Alex drukt hard op de versnelling, waardoor hun militair voertuig springt--alles in de nacht.

They come across German infantrymen, but the military vehicle rams into them and hangs onto them, causing it to jump when Alex presses hard on the accelerator. 0.text: Over two years have passed. Jude and Sue lead a wandering life, stopping wherever Jude can find work as a mason. However, he refuses to do any church work. At the little town of Kennetbridge, Arabella and Anny arrive one day. Arabella is now widowed and is in mourning and has come to Kennetbridge to see the laying of a foundation stone of a new chapel. She claims that she has now turned to religion for consolation. She suddenly spots Sue and Little Father Time selling cakes and gingerbread at a stall at the fair. She questions Sue and learns that Jude was very ill that winter, and they have therefore tried their hand at baking in an attempt to earn a living. Sue now has two children of her own and is expecting a third. The cakes Jude makes are shaped like Christminster colleges, with towers and pinnacles and traceried windows, indicating that Jude still has a passion for Christminster.

2.text: Two years have passed. Jude and Sue lead a nomadic existence. Jude finds truth in his work as a stonemason, but refuses to work for churches. In the small village of Kennetbridge, Arabella and Annie arrive one day. Arabella is now a widow and has come to Kennetbridge to see the foundation stone of a new chapel. She claims to have found religion for comfort. Suddenly, she discovers Sue and Old Time in a shop where they sell gingerbread and cookies. She asks Sue and learns that Jude was very ill that winter and tried to earn a living by baking bread. Sue now has two children and is expecting a third. The gingerbread that Jude makes is in the shape of Christminster colleges, with towers, pinnacles, and window frames, indicating that Jude still harbors a passion for Christminster.

0.text: A French Lord holds a showcase Extravaganza where all the important aristocrats attend. The host snubs the Marquis St. Evremonde and he leaves the reception angrily, ordering his driver to race through the Paris streets. He accidentally runs over a child whose father is Gaspard. He tosses the grief-stricken father a coin and Defarge emerges from the crowd to comfort Gaspard. He throws the coin back into the carriage as it speeds away. The Marquis travels to his country estate where he stops at the village he owns, near his home. A road mender claims he saw a man riding underneath the carriage, who, when it stopped, ran away. The Marquis tells Gabelle, the town official, to be on the lookout for the mystery man. The Marquis travels on to his chateau hoping to meet his nephew M. Charles who is traveling from England.

She says she will not help him make more money while ruining herself. Mr. Poyser worries that he will kick them off Hall Farm when it comes time to renew their lease. He laments the idea of going to live among strangers when it has been the pride of his family that they have land. Mrs. Poyser tells him not to worry about that until it happens

Mr. Poyer is concerned they may be displaced from Hall Farm under the revised rental conditions. He dislikes the notion of residing among outsiders, as the possession of land has long been a source of pride for their family. Mrs. Poyer urges him to be patient and observe how events unfold further.

0.text: Isabel stands, not wanting Lord Warburton to sit with her. They begin taking a stroll. It's clear that Lord Warburton has something specific on his mind. Surprise! Lord Warburton professes his love for Isabel. He asks her to marry him. Isabel reflects on how romantic and perfect the moment would have seemed to her three months ago. Right now, though, she's just not into it. Isabel promises Lord Warburton that she will consider his proposal, and not take too long before giving him an answer. Lord Warburton confesses that he's afraid of Isabel's mind. Isabel admits that she is, too. Forlorn, Lord Warburton tells Isabel that they don't have to live at Lockleigh if she doesn't like the moat - they can go anywhere. Overcome with disappointment, he leaves. Isabel, left alone again, knows that she won't marry Lord Warburton. Reflecting upon her choice, Isabel fears for herself.

0.text: The mayoral election comes up for Zenith, and the left-wing lawyer Seneca Doane is running. That means that Babbitt and his pro-business brotherhood need to fire up their election machine and get anyone other than Doane into office. They promote a candidate named Lucas Prout and Babbitt goes around giving speeches in support of Prout. Ultimately, Babbitt's efforts are able to get Lucas Prout elected mayor. The business community survives another big scare from organized labor. Now that he has an established reputation as a speechmaker, Babbitt is invited to all sorts of functions to give speeches about business and about the glory of Zenith. One of the main points in his speeches is that state universities should fire all professors who preach liberal or socialist views. As his star continues to rise in Zenith's social circles, Babbitt wonders how he ever could have doubted the joys of being a solid citizen.

2.text: In Zenith, later comes the mayor election with Seneca Doane, a left-wing lawyer, as a candidate. This means that Babbitt and his pro-business faction must activate their election machine and put someone else than Doane in office. They promote a candidate named Lucas Prout, and Babbitt goes around giving speeches on Prout's behalf. In the pessimistic scenario, Prout is elected as mayor. The business world is once again facing a major shock from organized labor. With his established reputation as a speaker, Babbitt is invited to various events to talk about business and Zenith's glory. One of the main points in his speeches is that all state colleges should fire professors expressing liberal or socialist views. As Babbitt's fame in Zenith's social circles continues to rise, he wonders how he ever had doubts about enjoying a solid bourgeois life.

0.text: The next day, Sue, having changed her mind as usual, writes Jude a note saying he must not come to Shaston. Jude writes back agreeing not to meet her. But on Easter Monday he gets a message from Mrs. Edlin saying that his aunt's health is sinking. Jude rushes to Marygreen to find Aunt Drusilla already dead. He informs Sue, who arrives for the funeral. After the funeral, Sue and Jude have a discussion about Aunt Drusilla's disapproval of marriage for the Fawleys. Sue confesses to an intense physical aversion to Phillotson, although she respects and likes him as a friend. Jude senses her unhappiness and laments the fact that he did not try to prevent her hasty marriage. Sue will not let Jude comfort her and goes off to Widow Edlin's cottage for the night. Later that night, Jude hears the cry of trapped rabbit, and, unable to bear it, he goes out and relieves it of further pain by putting it to death. He finds Sue awake at her window, and she breaks down and pours out all her suffering to him. She finally admits her mistake in not considering the full implications of marriage.

2.text: The next day, Sue writes to Jude, as she often does, her voice wavering, and asks him not to come to Shaston. Jude answers by agreeing not to meet her. 0.text: Once inside the chateau, in his elegant private rooms, the Marquis prepares for supper and awaits his nephew's arrival. When his nephew -- Charles Darnay -- arrives, the two exchange brief formalities and then, after the servants have left, Darnay tells his uncle that he is renouncing all ties to his family and to France. Although he is coolly polite, the Marquis' dislike for his nephew is apparent. Darnay equally despises his uncle, and the fear and hatred inspired by the Evremond name troubles him. Before they part, the Marquis asks about Darnay's relationship with Doctor Manette and Lucie and then smiles mysteriously. In the morning, the Marquis is discovered dead -- stabbed by a member of the Jacquerie.

She hopes to find that Osmond has met his match in Isabel. Henrietta visits Countess Gemini, asking whether she knows of Isabel's situation. The outlandish Countess is quite taken with the newspaper woman, and hopes that they can travel to Rome together - she desperately wants her name to appear in the papers. Henrietta's too busy to wait for Countess Gemini's departure, however, and wants see her friend as soon as possible. She plans to leave the next day. Henrietta runs into Caspar at the Uffizi, and they decide to leave for Rome together the next day. Caspar is somewhat hesitant, because he has mixed feelings for Henrietta, but he agrees to travel with her.

The she-wolf settles into the lair while One Eye instinctively goes in search of food for the soon-to-arrive pups. After his first foray, he returns with no food, but does find that the she-wolf has given birth. She is at first very protective of the pups, exercising her motherly, instinctual knowledge that the father could be a danger to the newborns. As time passes, however-and, importantly, once One Eye returns with food-she relaxes her guard.

0.text: The narrator takes the reader to the home of Mr. Aldophous Irwine, the rector of Broxton, where Hayslope is located. Mr. Irwine is playing chess with his mother, Mrs. Irwine, a socialite. Mr. Irwine is a bachelor because he has chosen to take care of his mother and two unmarried sisters, one of whom is chronically ill, rather than have his own family. Joshua Rann, the cobbler and parish clerk of Hayslope, comes to see Mr. Irwine to complain about the Methodists and Dinah. In particular, Mr. Rann complains about the wheelwright, Will Maskery, who is a Methodist and has made disparaging remarks about Mr. Irwine and Rann. Mr. Irwine laughs off the insults and tells Rann to leave Maskery to his own business. As Rann is leaving, Captain Arthur Donnithorne arrives to ask Mr. Irwine to go riding with him. Captain Donnithorne is the grandson and heir of the local landlord, Squire Donnithorne. Known throughout the village as 'the young squire,' he is a dashing man who is staying at the Squire's estate to recover from an injury in the army. Rann tells both Mr. Irwine and Captain Donnithorne about the death of Thias Bede, Adam's father

2.text:
At Mr. Aldous Irwine's residence in Broxton, where Hayslope is situated, Mr. Irwine, the bachelor rector, is engaged in a game of chess with his mother, Mrs. Irwine, a socialite. Joshua Rann, the local shoemaker and parish clerk, visits to voice his grievances against the Methodists and Dinah. He accuses Mr. Irwine of condoning insults from Will Maskery, a Methodist shoemaker, who allegedly disparaged both Mr. Irwine and Rann. Mr. Irwine denies the accusations and advises Rann to focus on his own affairs. As Rann departs, Captain Arthur Donnithorne, the grandson and heir of the local squire, Squire Donnithorne, arrives to invite Mr. Irwine for a ride. Captain Donnithorne, known as 'the young squire,' is an attractive man recuperating on the squire's estate from his military injuries. Rann shares the news of Thias Bede's demise, father of Adam, with both Mr. Irwine and Captain Donnithorne.

0.text: The mender of roads who spotted the man under the Marquis St. Evremonde's carriage accompanies Defarge to the wine-shop. In the garret where Doctor Alexandre Manette stayed, Defarge and Jacques One, Two, and Three listen to the road-mender describe what happened to Gaspard, the man who killed the Marquis. Gaspard, who murdered the Marquis for running down his child, went into hiding for nearly a year after the killing. The French authorities recently captured, jailed, and hanged him, and left his corpse dangling by the village fountain, with his shadow poisoning the atmosphere of the town. Monsieur and Madame Defarge later take the road-mender to Versailles, where the splendor of the court dazzles him. Caught up in the emotion of the experience, the road-mender cheers the King, Queen, and other nobles. The Defarges commend his behavior, feeling that it will fuel the courtiers' arrogance and ignorance of the revolutionary movement. Additionally, the Defarges believe that the sight of such luxury and finery will supply the road-mender with a focus for his hatred and violence in the future.

Gaspard, who killed the Marquis because he called out to his child, hid himself nearly a year after the murder. The French authorities recently arrested, detained, and beheaded him, and his body hangs at the village pump, poisoning the village mood with its shadow. Later, Madame and Monsieur Defarge took the four men with them to Versailles, where the splendor of the court left them astonished. Overwhelmed by the emotion of the experience, the four men screamed at the King, Queen, and other nobles. The Defarges praised their behavior, feeling that it exposed the courtiers' heartlessness and ignorance regarding the revolution. Additionally, they believed that the sight of such an opulent and magnificent environment would awaken their hatred and violence for the future.

(Note: In English, I use the same terms as in Dutch: 'count de St. Evremonde', 'French monarchy', 'town pump', 'surroundings', 'future' and 'revolution')

50.text:
Four men, who had discovered the body of count de St. Evremonde under their wagon, escorted Defarge to his shop. In Defarge's garage, where doctor Alexandre Manette lives, Defarge and three of the four men recounted the events surrounding Gaspard, who had killed the count for his children. Gaspard, who had lived in hiding for about a year after the murder,

had recently been arrested, imprisoned, and beheaded by the French monarchy. His body now hung by the town pump, casting a dark shadow over the village. Later, Madame and mr. Defarge took the four men with them to Versailles, presumably leaving them there before the revolution broke out. The tragic beauty and grandeur of the surroundings could only further provoke the hatred and atrocities of the future.

0.text: Fire Rises The French countryside lies ruined and desolate. An unidentified man, weary from travel, meets the mender of roads. They address each other as 'Jacques' to indicate their status as revolutionaries. The mender of roads directs the man to the chateau of the murdered Marquis. Later that night, the man sets the castle on fire. A rider from the chateau urges the village soldiers to help put out the fire and salvage the valuables there, but they refuse, and the villagers go inside their homes and put 'candles in every dull little pane of glass. The peasants nearly kill Gabelle, the local tax collector, but he escapes to the roof of his house, where he watches the chateau burn. The narrator reports that scenes such as this are occurring all over France

2.text:
I. Introductory remarks by the chairman:
A. 'Ladies and gentlemen, esteemed guests, welcome to this conference on sustainable energy solutions. Today, we will discuss innovative approaches to renewable energy sources and their implementation in our daily lives. I am pleased to introduce our first keynote speaker, Professor Jan van Dijk from the University of Amsterdam.'

B. 'Professor van Dijk, the floor is yours.'

II. Keynote speech by Professor Jan van Dijk:
A. 'Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, esteemed guests. I am honored to be here today to talk about the latest developments in solar energy technology. Solar energy is becoming increasingly important in our quest for sustainable energy solutions. The Netherlands, with its abundant sunshine, is an ideal place for the implementation of solar energy.'

B. 'Recent advancements in solar cell technology have led to significant improvements in efficiency and cost. For instance, the development of perovskite solar cells has shown a remarkable increase in efficiency, making them a promising alternative to traditional silicon-based solar cells.'

C. 'Moreover, the integration of solar energy into our daily lives is becoming more accessible and affordable. Solar panels can now be installed on rooftops, and solar power can be stored in batteries for use during peak hours or when the sun is not shining. This decentralization of energy production is a game-changer in the energy sector.'

III. Q&A session:
A. 'Question from the audience: What about the environmental impact of producing solar panels? Are they truly sustainable?'

B. 'Professor van Dijk: That's a valid concern. While the production of solar panels does require some resources and energy, the environmental impact is significantly lower than that of traditional energy sources. Moreover, the environmental footprint of solar panels is decreasing as technology advances and production methods improve.'

C. 'Question from the audience: What are the main challenges in implementing solar energy on a larger scale?'

D. 'Professor van Dijk: One of the main challenges is the intermittency of solar energy. Solar panels produce energy only when the sun is shining, so energy storage and grid integration are crucial for a stable energy supply. Additionally, the initial investment for solar panel installation can be high, but the long-term savings and environmental benefits make it a

0.text: Ajax and Diomedes run around calling out for Troilus to show his face. So they can smash it in. They bicker about who gets to fight him, until Troilus gets fed up and says that he'll take them both on at the same time.Seriously? Maybe not a good move, dude. They fight their way off the stage as Achilles and Hector show up, going at it with their swords. Hector is getting the better of Achilles and offers to let the guy take a break. This is such a weird battle, you guys. Achilles talks some trash and says something like 'I'll be back' as he runs off. Troilus runs back on stage and says that Ajax has captured Aeneas. He promises to rescue him and runs off. Next, an armored Greek soldier shows up, takes one look at Hector, and hightails it out of there. Hector says he really likes the guy's armor and wouldn't mind having it in his trophy case. Then he runs after the shiny trophy.

2.text:
Ajax and Diomedes encircle Troilus, calling him to come out so they can attack. Arguing over who should fight him, Troilus is ready and states that he will take on both.

Why? Perhaps not the best option, gentlemen. They fight each other tooth and nail, just like Achilles and Hector when they appear, with swords in hand. Hektor gains the upper hand and offers him a pause. This is an odd fight scene, your two. Achilles sets up a camp site and leaves. Troilus returns to the battlefield and says that Ajax had held Aeneas captive. He promises to free him and leaves. Then, a Greek soldier in armor suddenly appears, looks at Hector, and quickly retreats. Hector says he greatly enjoys the armor and wants to add it to his trophy case. He runs towards it.

4.text:
Ajax and Diomedes encircle Troilus and call him out to fight. While they quarrel amongst themselves about who should engage him, Troilus is ready and says he will face both.

Gentlemen, they fight each other repeatedly, just like Achilles and Hector when they appear, with swords in hand. Hector gains the upper hand and offers him a respite. This is an unusual battle scene, gentlemen. Achilles sets up camp and leaves. Troilus returns to the battlefield and says Aeneas was held by Ajax. He promises to free him and departs. Suddenly, a Greek soldier in armor appears, looks at Hector, and quickly retreats. Hector finds it amusing and wants to add it to his trophy chest. He rushes towards the armor.

6.text:
Here is the English translation of the passage:

Ajax, Heerennen, and Diomedes encircle Troilus and call out to him to fight. While they argue among themselves about who will engage him, Troilus stands ready. He declares that he will take on both of them.

They fight each other repeatedly, just like Achilles and Hector when they appear, with swords in hand. Hector gains the upper hand and proposes a truce. This is an odd battle, heralds. Achilles sets up camp and departs. Troilus reappears on the battlefield, announcing that Aeneas had been seized by Ajax. He promises to free him and departs. Suddenly, a Greek soldier in armor charges in, looks at Hector, and then away. Hector finds it amusing and intends to add it to his trophy chest. He rushes towards the armor.

8.text:
Ajax, Heerennen, and Diomedes encircle Troilus and call out to him to fight. While they quarrel amongst themselves about who will engage him, Troilus stands ready. He declares that he will take on both of them.

They fight each other repeatedly, just as Achilles and Hector do when they appear, with swords in hand. Hector gains the upper hand and proposes a truce. This is an unusual battle, heralds. Achilles sets up camp and departs. Troilus re-emerges on the battlefield and reports that Aeneas has been taken by Ajax. He promises to free him and departs. Suddenly, a Greek soldier in armor bursts in, looks at Hector and then away. Hector finds it amusing and intends to add it to his trophy chest. He approaches the armor.

(Translation of the Dutch text provided into English)

10.text:
Ajax, Heerennen and Diomedes encircle Troilus, calling out to him to fight. While they quarrel amongst themselves about who will take him in, Troilus remains ready. He claims he can defeat both.

They engage in combat repeatedly, just like Achilles and Hector when they first clashed, with swords in hand. Hector emerges victorious and proposes a truce. This battle is strange, heralds. Achilles sets up camp and departs. Troilus reappears on the battlefield, announcing that Aeneas has been captured by Ajax. He promises to free him and departs. Suddenly, a Greek soldier in armor rushes in, looks at Hector and leaves. Hector finds this amusing and plans to add something to his trophy collection. He advances towards the armor.

13.text: Ajax, Heerennen, and Diomedes encircle Troilus and call out to him to join the fight. While they argue among themselves who will approach him, Troilus remains ready. He boasts that he can defeat both of them. They engage in repeated battles, just like Achilles and Hector did in their first encounter, with swords in hand. Hector wins and places a trophy on his helmet. O heralds, proclaim it. Achilles sets up camp and departs. Troilus appears on the battlefield, announces that Aeneas has been captured by Ajax, and promises to free him. He departs. Suddenly, a Greek soldier in armor rushes in, looks at Hector, and leaves. Hector finds this amusing and comes up with something for his trophy collection. He steps forward.

16.text:
Ajax, Hecuba and Diomedes surround Troilus and call him to join the fight. While they argue among themselves who should approach him, Troilus remains ready. He promises to defeat both of them. They fought repeatedly, just as Achilles and Hector did in their first encounter, with swords in hand. Hector wins and places a trophy on his helmet. O heralds, proclaim it. Achilles sets up camp and departs. Troilus appears on the battlefield, announces that Aeneas has been captured by Ajax, and promises to free him. He departs. Suddenly, a Greek soldier in armor runs in and looks at Hector before leaving. Hector finds it amusing and goes to his trophy collection.

Translation:

Ajax, Hecuba en Diomedes omringen Troilus en roepen hem op om mee te vechten. Terwijl zij onder elkaar ruzie maken wie hem aan moet benadering, blijft Troilus klaar. Hij belooft beide te verslaan. Ze vochten herhaaldelijk, net zoals Achilles en Hektor in hun eerste ontmoeting, met zwaarden in de hand. Hektor wint en plaats een trofee op zijn helm. O heralden, roep het uit. Achilles stelt zijn kamp op en vertrekt. Troilus verschijnt op het slagveld, maakt bekend dat Aeneas door Ajax is gevangengenomen, en belooft hem te bevrijden. Hij vertrekt. Plotseling rent een Griekse soldaat in pansen in en keek naar Hektor voordat hij wegging. Hektor vond het amusant en ging naar zijn trofeenverzameling.

English:

Ajax, Hecuba and Diomedes surround Troilus and call him to join the fight. While they argue among themselves who should approach him, Troilus remains ready. He promises to defeat both of them. They fought repeatedly, just as Achilles and Hector did in their first encounter, with swords in hand. Hector wins and places a trophy on his helmet. O heralds, proclaim it. Achilles sets up camp and departs.

20.text: Troilus surrounded by Ajax, Hecuba, and Diomedes, who encouraged him to join the fight. While they hesitated among themselves who would approach him, Troilus remains ready. He promises to defeat both. They fought repeatedly, just as Achilles and Hector did in their first encounter, with swords in their hands. Hector won and placed a trophy on his helmet. O heralds, announce it. Achilles sets up camp and departs.

25.text: Troilus surrounded by Ajax, Hecuba, and Diomedes, tried to persuade him to join their fight. While they were indecisive among themselves on who would approach him, Troilus remained ready. He promised to defeat both of them. They fought each other several times, just as Achilles and Hector did in their first encounter, with swords in their hands. 0.text: Joe Welling lives with his mother in Winesburg. Though a man of small stature, he is like a 'living volcano'. He is subject to fits of ideas, whereupon he becomes uncontrollable, words spout from his mouth in torrents, and the person who is his victim then has no escape. He works as an agent for the standard Oil Company, but he can accost anyone on the road and rapidly begin shooting words at him. He is a terror for the Winesburg citizens. But when Joe organizes the baseball club, he is considered a savior, as he can channel his ideas and excitement into the players and make them win. Joe falls in love with Sarah king a lean, sad-looking woman. Her brother Tom is considered dangerous, and so is his father Edward, the people of Winesburg can't help laughing at the odd pair but are afraid for Joe. George Willard reports his meeting with the two Kings. Apparently, Joe has managed to sweep away the two, by his torrent of words and ideas. His ideas have managed to perplex the two men and have given them no chance to counter attack Joe.

2.text: Joe Welling lives with his mother in Winesburg. Despite his small stature, he is like a 'living volcano.' He is subject to outbursts of ideas, during which he becomes unstoppable, words pour out of his mouth in abundance and the person he directs them towards, has no escape. He works for the Standard Oil Company as an agent, but suddenly he can attack everyone he encounters and shoot words at them. He is a terrifying figure for the citizens of Winesburg. But when Joe organizes the baseball club, he is seen as a savior, because he can pour his ideas and enthusiasm into the players and help them win. Joe is in love with Sarah King, a thin, sad-looking woman. Her brother Tom is considered dangerous, and even her father Edward, the people of Winesburg can think of no other way to describe the odd couple than laughing at them. But George Willard meets the two Kings. According to him, Joe drove the two men away with his stream of ideas and words. His ideas confused the two men and gave them no chance to oppose Joe.

100.text:
Joe Welling lives in Winesburg with his mother. He is of small build, but a 'living volcano.' Sensitively reacting to outbursts of ideas, during such periods many words flow from his mouth, and there is no limit for the person who is with him. He works for the Standard Oil Company, but suddenly he can attack and mock everyone. He is a terrifying figure for the inhabitants of Winesburg. But when Joe organizes the baseball club, he is regarded as a savior, because he injects his ideas and enthusiasm into the players and helps them win. Joe is afraid of Sarah King, a thin, sadistic woman. Her brother Tom is considered dangerous by the inhabitants of Winesburg, and they think that her husband Edward is a puppet of Sarah. But George Willard meets the two Kings. According to George, they were too much influenced by Joe's ideas and oratorical skills.

Translation:

Joe Welling woont bij zijn moeder in Winesburg. Hij is van kleine bouw, maar een 'levend vulkaan.' Sensitief reagerend op uitbarstingen van ideen, tijdens dergelijke perioden stromen er veel woorden uit zijn mond, en er is geen beperking voor de persoon die bij hem is. Hij werkt voor de Standard Oil Company, maar plotseling kan hij iedereen aanvallen en spotten. Hij is een vreeselijke figuur voor de bewoners van Winesburg. Maar wanneer Joe de honkbalclub organiseert, wordt hij beschouwd als een reddenaar, want hij injecteert zijn ideen en enthousiasme in de spelers en helpt hen te winnen. Joe is bang voor Sarah King, een dunne, sadistische vrouw. Haar broer Tom wordt door de bewoners van Winesburg beschouwd als gevaarlijk, en zij denken dat haar man Edward een poppet van Sarah is. Maar George Willard ontmoet de twee Kings. Volgens George waren zij te sterk benvloed door Joes ideen en oratorische vaardigheden.

0.text: During their layover in New York, Paul wants to see the Aquitania, declaring that he 'Always wanted to go to Europe'. As they stare at the line, Paul becomes so tense and agitated that they have to leave. In Maine, George and Paul spend their time relaxing and sitting at the edge of a wharf. For the week before their families arrive, the men indulge themselves by sleeping late, chewing tobacco, playing poker late into the night, and not bathing every day. They view the vacation as a chance to get 'a good rest. and start over again'. Over the course of the week, Paul becomes increasingly relaxed and cheerful, whereas George becomes increasingly weary and overwrought. When his family arrives, he is agitated again and reminded of his troublesome sense of obligation, though he is able to enjoy spending time with Ted and feels somewhat rejuvenated

2.text: In New York, during their stopover, Paul de Aquitania wants to see the Statue of Liberty and declares that he 'Always want to go to Europe.' While passing by, Paul gets so excited and energized that they have to leave. In Maine, George and Paul extend their stay by relaxing at the waterfront. In the week before their families arrive, the gentlemen neglect themselves, cut tobacco, gamble late at night and don't bathe every day. They see the vacation as an opportunity to 'Rest well and start anew.' During the week, Paul grows increasingly joyful, while George becomes more morally exhausted and impatient. Upon the arrival of his family, he is restored and recalls the uncomfortable feeling of obligation, but enjoys the time with Ted and feels somewhat rejuvenated.

4.text: In New York, during their stopover, Paul of Aquitaine wishes to see the Liberty Flag and declares, 'I have always wanted to go to Europe.' During their journey toward there, Paul becomes so excited and restless that they have to leave. In Maine, George and Paul extend their stay by resting by the water. In the week before the arrival of their families, the gentlemen neglect themselves, cut tobacco, gamble in the late evening, and don't bathe every day. They see the vacation as an opportunity 'To enjoy peace and start a new life.' During the week, Paul grows happier, while George becomes more burdened and impatient. Upon the arrival of his family, he recovers and recalls the uncomfortable feeling of obligation, but enjoys the time with Ted and feels somewhat rejuvenated.

6.text:
In New York, during their stopover, Paul of Aquitaine wishes to see the Freedom Flag in New York: 'I have always longed for Europe.' During their journey there, Paul becomes so excited and impatient that they have to leave. In Maine, George and Paul extend their stay by resting by the water. In the week before the arrival of their families, the gentlemen neglect themselves, cut tobacco, play in the late evening and don't bathe every day. They see the vacation as an opportunity 'To enjoy peace and start a new life.' During the week, Paul becomes happier, while George becomes more restless and impatient. Upon the arrival of his family, he recovers and recalls the uncomfortable feeling of obligation, but enjoys the time with Ted and feels a little refreshed.

Translation:
In New York, tijdens hun tussenlanding, wil Paul van Aquitani de Vrijheidsvlag in New York zien: 'Ik heb altijd gewild naar Europa.' Tijdens hun reis daarheen wordt Paul zo opgewonden en ongeduldig dat ze er vertrekken moeten. In Maine verlenen George en Paul hun verblijf door bij het water te rusten. In de week voordat het gezin aan komt, verwaarlozen de heren zichzelf, snijden tabak, spelen in de late avond en baden niet elke dag. Ze zien de vakantie als een kans 'Om vrede te genieten en een nieuw leven te beginnen.' Tijdens de week wordt Paul gelukkiger, terwijl George meer lastig en ongeduldig wordt. Bij het aankomen van zijn gezin herstelt hij en herinnert zich de ongemakkelijke voeling van verplichting, maar geniett hij toch de tijd met Ted en voelt hij zich iets opgefrisseld.

0.text: Jim takes his grandparents to have their picture taken, and while at the photographer, sees an elaborately framed portrait of Antonia's baby. He decides that he must see her and is happy that Antonia is not too ashamed to hide her baby from public view. Larry Donovan is a passenger conductor for the railroad and acts like a superior, underappreciated individual. He spends a lot of time getting women to sympathize with his sad plight, and he convinces them that he is much better than he really is. Jim goes to Mrs. Harling and tells her he wants to know about Antonia's aborted marriage. She tells him to go ask the Widow Steavens, who knows the entire story and loves to talk.

0.text: In the opening chapter, the period in which the novel is set is described. The story begins about fifteen years before the French Revolution. It is a time when many people think they live in the best of times, while others condemn it as the worst of times. The kings of England and France are both mediocre rulers, and they believe in their divine rights. People are put to death for the slightest of crimes. The condition in France is very bad, for there is a total disregard for the common people by the aristocracy; injustice, cruelty, and oppression are rampant. The aristocracy is unaware that the masses are preparing for the revolution by turning timber into guillotines and farm carts into tumbrels to convey people to the guillotine. In England, too, lawlessness and poverty prevail. Even the colonies in America are up in arms against their English rulers, and the attempts of the American colonies to obtain freedom are not taken seriously.
