Both the English and French monarchs are mediocre rulers, and they believe in their God-given rights. For minor offenses, people are sentenced to death. The situation in France is very poor, as the aristocracy disregards the people; tyranny, wicked deeds, and oppression reign. The aristocracy is unaware of the fact that the masses are preparing for the revolution by changing wood into guillotines and tumbrels to transport people to the guillotine. In England, there is widespread ignorance and poverty. The American colonies are also in rebellion against their English rulers, and their attempts to gain freedom are ignored.

0.text: It seems that Rosamond refuses to learn any lessons from her situation; to appease her vanity, she starts to think of Will Ladislaw, and imagines that he must love her instead of Dorothea, because she is so beautiful and charming. She continues to blame her husband for her unhappiness, not her rabid materialism; everything is someone else's fault, and she is still a creature who is perfectly innocent of blame. She gets a letter from Will, saying that he will be paying a visit sometime soon; Rosamond is cheered up by this, and decides to send out invitations for a dinner party. Of course, all invitations are denied, and Rosamond is still ignorant as to the reason why; she goes to visit her parents, and they tell her the terrible news. When she goes home, she tells her husband that she has heard about everything; she then reiterates that they must go to London, to lessen her suffering. He cannot stand to hear this, and storms out, without taking the time to correct her or explain anything.

0.text: As the travelers traverse the length of Utah, a Mormon missionary boards the train and proceeds to give all who will listen to him an odd lesson in Mormon history, practice, theory, and culture. Passepartout is curious at first and joins the lecture, but he manages to escape when he finds it extremely boring. At Ogden the train stops and another Mormon man hurries onto the train, having just had a fight at home. Passepartout asks him how many wives he has and the man answers that he only has one. Passepartout finds this different from the other Mormons and possibly a better idea because having more than one wife can be a hot mess.

2.text:

Passepartout asks him how many wives he has and the man answers that he only has one. Passepartout finds that different from other Mormons and possibly a better idea, as one woman might be preferable to holding more than one.

0.text: Jane's students become more familiar and endeared to her, and Jane becomes quite popular among them. At night, though, she has troubling nightmares that involve Rochester. Jane continues to pay attention to the relationship between St. John and Rosamond, who often visits the school when she knows St. John will be there. Rosamond asks Jane to draw her portrait, and as she is working on it one day, St. John pays her a visit. He gives her a new book of poetry and looks at the drawing. She offers to draw him a duplicate, and then boldly declares that he ought to marry Rosamond. St. John admits that he loves her and is tempted by her beauty, but he explains that he refuses to allow worldly affection to interfere with his holy duties. The flirtatious, silly, and shallow Rosamond would make a terrible wife for a missionary. Suddenly, St. John notices something on the edge of Jane's paper and tears off a tiny piece--Jane is not certain why. With a peculiar look on his face, he hurries from the room

2.text:
In English:

Jane's pupils are becoming more and more attached to her and fond of her, and she is growing more popular among them. But in the night, she has restless dream images of Rochester. Yet Jane continues to deal with the relationship between St. John and Rosamond, who regularly visits the school when she knows he will be there. Rosamond asks herself to be painted by Jane, and while she works on her portrait for an entire day, St. John enters. He gives her a new book of poetry and looks at her painting. She offers to make a copy for him, and then makes a casual remark that he should marry Rosamond. St. John confesses that he loves her and is attracted to her beauty, but he declares that he will not let himself be influenced by worldly love in his sacred duties. Rosamond, the laughing, pale, and shallow one, would be a disgrace for a missionary. Suddenly, St. John notices something at the edge of Jane's paper and takes a small piece of it away--Jane remains unclear as to why. With a strange look, he leaves the room.

4.text:
In English: Jane's pupils are growing more fond and affectionate towards her, and she is becoming increasingly popular among them. But in the night, she has restless dreams of Rochester. Jane is dealing with the relationship between St. John and Rosamond, who regularly visits the school when she knows he will be there. Rosamond wonders if Jane will paint her portrait, and while she is engrossed in painting all day, St. John arrives. He brings her a new collection of poems and looks at her painting. She offers to make a copy for him, and then makes a careless remark that he should marry Rosamond. St. John confesses that he loves and is attracted to her beauty, but he declares that he will not let worldly love distract him from his sacred duties. Rosamond, the merry, fair-complexioned and shallow one, would be a disgrace to a missionary. Suddenly, St. John notices something at the edge of Jane's paper and takes a small piece away--the reason for which is unclear to Jane. With a strange look, he leaves the room.

Jane is bezig met de relatie tussen St. John en Rosamond, die regelmatig de school bezoekt wanneer zij weet dat hij daar zal zijn. Rosamond denkt aan of Jane haar zal tekenen, en terwijl zij de hele dag aan het tekenen is, komt St. John. Hij brengt haar een nieuwe bundel gedichten mee en keek naar haar tekenwerk. Zij biedt aan om een kopie te maken voor hem, en dan maakt zij een onzorgelijke opmerking dat hij Rosamond moet trouwen. St. John bevestigt dat hij van haar houdt en aangetrokken is door haar schoonheid, maar hij verklaart dat hij in zijn heilige plichten geen wereldlijke liefde zal laten afleiden. Rosamond twijfelt of Jane haar herkent, en heel de dag lang terwijl zij te teken is, komt St. John. Hij brengt haar een nieuwe bundel gedichten en keekt naar haar tekeningen. Zij biedt aan om een kopie te maken voor hem, en dan maakt zij onbedoeld een opmerking, waarmee zij hem aanmoedigt te trouwen met Rosamond. St. John bevestigt zijn liefde en aant

0.text: The group treads barefoot through a stream in order to hide its tracks. They pass a pond, and Hawkeye tells the group it is filled with corpses of slain French soldiers. As they near the besieged Fort William Henry, they encounter a French sentinel. Heyward talks to him in French, distracting him while Chingachgook sneaks up to the sentinel, kills him, and scalps him. Firing breaks out between English troops protecting the fort and French forces, and the crossfire puts the party in danger. Thick fog conceals them, however, and they attempt to find their way to the fort through the sounds of battle. The French forces pursue them, but they arrive at the fort safely. As they enter the fort, Colonel Munro weeps and embraces his daughters

2.text: The group swims through a creek, hiding their footprints. They pass a pond, and Hawkeye tells the group that it is filled with bodies of French soldiers they had killed. Approaching Fort William Henry, which is under siege, they encounter a French trumpeter. Heyward speaks with him in French, distracting him while Chingachgook shoots him from behind and decapitates him. A gunfight ensues between the English troops guarding the fort and the French troops, and their crossfire threatens the group. However, a thick fog shields them, and they try to reach the fort by sneaking past the sounds of battle. The French troops pursue them, but they reach the fort safely. Upon entering the fort, Colonel Munro wept and embraced his daughters.

The groep zwemt door een beek, hun voetsporen verborgen. Ze passeren een vijver, en Hawkeye waarschuwt de groep dat de Fransen, die enkele van hen gedood hadden, op zoek zijn. Aan Fort William Henry, onder belegering, ontmoeten ze een Frans trompetter. Heyward spreekt met hem in Frans, maar hij wordt overmeesterd door Chingachgook, die hem in de rug steekt. Ontstaat een gevecht tussen de Engelse versterkingen en de Franse soldaten, en hun kruisvuur bedreigt de groep. Maar een dikke mist beschermt hen, zodat ze ongeschonden het fort binnenkomen, geleid door de geluiden van de strijd. De Fransen jagen hen op, maar kunnen de bewoners van het fort niet schaden.

0.text: Affery goes to bed. Then she has what she thinks is a dream. She 'dreams' that she goes downstairs and sees Flintwinch talking to himself - no, literally, talking to a double of himself. She totally freaks out and becomes sort of catatonic and paralyzed with fear. The double picks up an iron box and goes out the door. Flintwinch sees Affery on the stairs and pushes her back to the bedroom silently. Then he chokes the living daylights out of her, while shaking her awake. He tells her she's been having a nightmare and if she has another one, he's going to give her a big dose of medicine. You know, the beating-the-crap-out-of-you kind of medicine.

2.text: Affy falls asleep. Deep in slumber, she thinks she is dreaming. She 'dreams' that she is going down and Flintwinch even speaks with a doppelganger of himself - yes, literally, with himself. Flintwinch sees Affy on the stairs and pushes her back into the room. Subsequently, he covers her with life within her, while waking her up. He tells her that she had a nightmare and if she gets another one, she will receive a large dose of medication. You know, the type of medication that you make from it.

0.text: Dr. Seward continues to note in his diary. Mina Harker telegrams that she is coming by train and she has important news. Van Helsing, who is a great admirer of her, is delighted. She arrives and stays in the asylum. Dr. Seward shows her his phonograph, and she is fascinated by it. She tells them that Jonathan has seen Dracula. Jonathan arrives on September 30, and they try to trace Dracula. Renfield's reaction make Dr. Seward realize that the next door house is Count Draculas, which is confirmed by Jonathan, who has done the sale of purchase Arthur Holmwood and Quincey Morris join in the pursuit of Dracula.

2.text: In his diary, Dr. Seward writes that Mina Harker telegraphed that she is coming with important news. Van Helsing, who holds her in high esteem, is pleased. She arrives and stays at the asylum. Dr. Seward shows her his phonograph, and she is fascinated by it. She tells them that she has seen Jonathan Harker. Jonathan is due on the 30th of September, and they try to track down Dracula. Renfield's reaction makes Dr. Seward realize that the house on the other side of the street is Dracula's, which is confirmed by Jonathan, who mentions the sale of the house to Arthur Holmwood and Quincey Morris in his account, joining the hunt for Dracula.

Renfield's reaction makes Dr. Seward notice that the house is on Dracula's way, which is confirmed by Jonathan in his report and he joins the hunt for Dracula.

0.text: In the village, people gather to hear Dinah's preaching. The tavern manager, Mr. Casson, comes outside to see what the commotion is, and he meets a stranger on a horse. He and the stranger have a discussion about Dinah, and Mr. Casson says he believes it is inappropriate for a woman to preach on the village green. As Dinah begins to preach, she draws in the villagers with her soft, loving voice, and the stranger stays to listen to her despite his reservations about a woman preacher. Dinah's sermon tells about the love Jesus has for the poor and encourages the townspeople to give up their sins and do good in the world. The villagers accept her slowly, and by the time she concludes her preaching, many of them are moved to tears

2.text: In the village, people gather to hear Dinah's preaching. The innkeeper, Mr. Casson, steps outside to see what the commotion is about, and encounters a traveler on horseback. They engage in conversation about Dinah, and Mr. Casson reveals his surprise at a woman preaching in the village square. As Dinah begins to preach, she draws the villagers in with her soft, loving voice, and the traveler remains listening despite his doubts about a female preacher. Dinah's preaching is about the love that Jesus has for the poor and encourages the villagers to confess their sins and do good in the world. Gradually, they accept her, and when she ends her sermon, many of them are in tears.

0.text: Hester has heard that certain influential citizens feel Pearl should be taken from her. Alarmed, Hester sets out with Pearl for Governor Bellingham's mansion to deliver gloves that he ordered. More important, however, Hester plans to plead for the right to keep her daughter. Pearl has been especially dressed for the occasion in an elaborate scarlet dress, embroidered with gold thread. On the way to the governor's mansion, Hester and Pearl are accosted by a group of Puritan children. When they taunt Pearl, she shows a temper as fiery as her appearance, driving the children off with her screams and threats. Reaching the Governor's large, elaborate, stucco frame dwelling, Hester and Pearl are admitted by a bondsman. Inside a heavy oak hall, Hester and Pearl stand before Governor Bellingham's suit of armor. In its curved, polished breastplate, both Hester's scarlet A and Pearl are distorted. Meanwhile, as Hester contemplates her daughter's changed image, a small group of men approaches. Pearl becomes quiet out of curiosity about the men who are coming down the path.

2.text:
Hester is convinced that certain influential citizens want to take Pearl away from her. Anxiously, she sets out with Pearl towards Governor Bellingham's residence, intending to hand him the pearls he had ordered. But more importantly, she defends herself to keep her daughter. For this occasion, Hester dresses Pearl in a complex red gown adorned with gold thread. On their way to the governor's residence, they are interrupted by a group of Puritan children. When they insult Pearl, Hester shows her rage as hot as her appearance, scaring the children away with her screams and threats. Upon reaching the impressive stone building of the governor, they are allowed in by a doorman. In the heavily carved wooden foyer, Hester and Pearl stand before Governor Bellingham's open fireplace. In his carved, gleaming breastplate, Hester's red A and Pearl's distorted forms are visible. Meanwhile, Hester ponders her changed daughter, while a small group of men approach. Pearl remains still, she seems fascinated by the men who depart.

(English translation:)

Hester suspects that certain influential citizens wish to take Pearl from her. In his intricately carved, gleaming breastplate, Hester's red A and Pearl's distorted forms are visible. Meanwhile, Hester reflects on her transformed daughter, while a small group of men draw near. Pearl remains still, she seems captivated by the men who depart.

0.text: Locksley tells the Prior that he will be freed only on payment of a ransom. He asks Isaac to decide what the ransom should be. Isaac says six hundred crowns. Asked to name Isaac's ransom, the Prior sets it at a thousand crowns. Both men protest loudly about the large sums expected of them. Locksley lowers Isaac's ransom to five hundred crowns, since he knows that Isaac will also have to pay a ransom to free Rebecca from De Bois-Guilbert. Locksley has been cared for in the past by Rebecca when he was sick, so this accounts for his relative generosity to Isaac. Locksley also persuades the Prior to intervene with De Bois-Guilbert in order to win Rebecca's freedom. After lengthy negotiations, Isaac goes off on his mission. The Black Knight departs, his real identity still a mystery

2.text:
Locksley tells the Prior that he will only show himself outside if ransom is paid. He asks Isaac for the ransom amount. Isaac responds with six hundred crowns. When asked what his ransom is called, the Prior sets it at a thousand crowns. Both men strongly protest against the high demands being made of them. Locksley lowers Isaac's ransom to five hundred crowns because he knows that Isaac also has to pay ransom to free Rebecca from De Bois-Guilbert. Locksley had helped Rebecca in the past when she was ill, which is why he behaves relatively generously towards Isaac. Locksley manages to convince the Prior to agree to the release of De Bois-Guilbert in order to ensure the safe release of Rebecca. After lengthy negotiations, Isaac departs on his mission. The Black Knight departs, his true identity still a secret.

(Translation in Dutch:

Lockley vertelt de Prior dat hij zich enkel buiten laat zien indien losgeld betaald wordt. Hij vraagt Isaac het losgeldbedrag aan te geven. Isaac antwoordt met zeshonderd kroonen. Wanneer men Isaac vraagt wat zijn losgeld heet, stelt de Prior het op duizend kroonen. Beide mannen protesteerden sterk tegen de hoge eisen die van hen gevraagd werden. Lockley laat Israels losgeld afdalen naar vijfhonderd kroonen omdat hij weet dat Isaac ook losgeld moet betalen om Rebecca vrij te krijgen van De Bois-Guilbert. Lockley had Rebecca in het verleden geholpen toen zij ziek was, waardoor hij zich relatief generoselijk gedraagt tegenover Isaac. Lockley lukt het om de Prior over te halen zich in te schikken voor de vrijlating van De Bois-Guilbert om Rebecca's vrijlating veilig te stellen. Na langdurige onderhandelingen vertrekt Isaac op zijn missie. De Zwarte Ridder vertrekt, zijn echte identiteit nog steeds een geheim.)

0.text: The men run off to fight, and Roxane collapses over Christian's body. Cyrano leans down and whispers into Christian's ear that he told Roxane the secret, and that she chose Christian. The battle breaks out all around them and Christian closes his eyes, dead. Next to Christian's heart, Roxane finds the farewell letter that Cyrano wrote for Christian to give her. She faints with grief, and Cyrano sends Ragueneau and de Guiche to take her away and protect her. Carbon emerges from the fighting, twice wounded. But the army has returned, and the men will win if they can hold out only a little longer. Cyrano tells Carbon not to worry. Now, he says, he has two deaths to avenge: Christian's and his own. Cyrano charges into battle. When he hears a Spaniard ask, 'Who are these men who are so eager for death. he begins to sing the song of the Cadets of Gascoyne. Cyrano charges off into a hail of bullets, singing as he fights.

0.text: The scene opens in Caesar's house. It is a stormy night and Calphurnia has dreamed of Caesar's murder. She asks a servant to instruct an augurer to interpret the signs, and she implores Caesar on her knees to stay at home. The servant returns, advising that Caesar should stay at home, and eventually he agrees, and he will advise Antony to tell the Senators that he is sick. Decius Brutus enters and he gives his interpretation to the omen. The vision concerned Romans dipping their hands in the blood flowing from Caesar's statue. Decius says that Calphurnia's dream represents Caesar's blood reviving Rome and the Romans are smiling because they are renewed. Decius goes on to suggest that the Senate will ridicule Caesar for being governed by his wife's dreams. Caesar changes his mind and goes to the Capitol. Caesar arrives and he welcomes Antony who is suffering the effects of partying the previous night.

Caesar arrives and greets Antony, who still feels the effects of the nighttime festivities.

Caesar arrives and salutes Antony, who continues to grapple with the uneasy emotions of the preceding night.

0.text: On the tenth morning, Doctor Alexandre Manette awakens fully recovered and unaware that anything unusual has transpired. Mr. Lorry tactfully conveys to the Doctor what has happened and asks what caused the relapse and how it can be prevented. The Doctor explains that he expected the relapse, which was caused by the revival of certain memories. He believes that the worst is over and doubts that another relapse could occur; if one did, it would most likely result from an intense experience that revived those same memories. Mr. Lorry also questions the wisdom of keeping the shoemaking bench and materials, pointing out that their presence reminds the Doctor of the past that has caused him so much pain. Uneasily agreeing, Doctor Manette requests that Mr. Lorry dispose of the bench and tools without him. Therefore, Mr. Lorry and Miss Pross bury the tools and burn the shoemaking bench after the Doctor leaves to join Lucie and Darnay on their trip.

2.text: On the tenth morning, doctor Alexandre Manette fully recovered and was unaware of anything unusual having occurred. Mr. Lorry showed him with great tact how it had transpired and asked him what had caused it and how it could be prevented. The doctor answered that he had expected a relapse, caused by the resurfacing of certain memories. He had doubts about the gravity of the situation and thought it possible that another relapse might occur; if that were the case, it would likely stem from an intimate experience that brought those same memories to the surface again. Mr. Lorry also had doubts about the wisdom of keeping the bank and the tools, as their presence reminded the doctor of the past that had caused him so much pain. Nervously and uncertainly, the doctor asked Mr. Lorry to remove the bank and the tools without his presence. Therefore, the bank and the tools were buried and burned by Mr. Lorry and Miss Pross after the doctor's departure.

0.text: The Underground Man wishes that his constant state of inaction were simply because of laziness. That sure would make things easier. And at least then, he says, he could respect himself. Also, at least he would have certainty. If someone asked what he was, the answer would be clear: a lazy person! For example: the Underground Man once knew a guy who was a connoisseur of Lafitte . That was pretty much the guy's only defining feature, but at least he had a defining feature. So he died a happy man. The point is that the Underground Man has no such vocation. If he could pick something to be, he'd pick...mmm...a glutton . A glutton who can appreciate 'everything sublime and beautiful.' The more he thinks about it, the more he realizes that should have been what his life was about: appreciating the sublime and beautiful. He realizes that such a life would probably have meant a lot of crying. Any time someone did anything beautiful or sublime, he would have wept in awe. He also would have gotten fat and red in the nose.

2.text:
The Underground Man wishes that his persistent unwillingness were merely a matter of uniqueness. That would make things so much simpler. At least he would then value himself. Furthermore, he would have certainty. If someone asked him who he was, his answer would be clear: a unique person! For instance, the Underground Man knew a man who was an expert in Lafitte. That was his only defining characteristic, but at least he had one. He died a happy man. The point is that the Underground Man has no such calling. If he could be anything, he...mmm...would be a freak. A freak who could value everything as unique and beautiful. He thinks more and more about it, and he notices more and more clearly that that was probably it: valuing everything as unique and beautiful. Such a life would probably have meant a lot of weeping. Every time someone did something beautiful or unique, he would probably be astonished and probably turn red-nosed.

(Note: In this translation, I assumed that 'Lafitte' refers to a specific person or subject, as in the original text. If 'Lafitte' is a metaphor or a symbol in the original text, please let me know so I can adjust the translation accordingly.)

The Underground Man longs for his persistent unwillingness to be nothing more than a quirk. It would make things much easier. At the very least, he would then appreciate himself. Moreover, he would have confidence. If someone asked him who he was, he could give a clear answer: a unique individual! For example, the Underground Man knew a man who was an expert in Lafitte. That was his only defining trait, but at least he had one. He died a contented man. The essence of the matter is that the Underground Man does not have such a calling. If he could be anything, he...mmm...would be a misfit. A misfit who could appreciate everything as unique and beautiful. He ponders this more and more, and he realizes more and more clearly that this was likely the case: appreciating everything as unique and beautiful. Such a life would probably have been marked by a great deal of tears. Every time someone did something beautiful or unique, he would probably be taken aback and probably blush.

4.text:
The Underground Man wished that his obstinacy were nothing more than a sign of unique character. That would make things much simpler. At least he would value himself. Furthermore, he would have certainty. If someone asked him who he was, he could give a clear answer: a unique person! For instance, The Underground Man knew a man who was an expert in Lafitte. That was his only defining characteristic, but at least he had one. He died a happy man. The point is that The Underground Man doesn't have that. If he could be anything, he...mmm...would be an impudent person. An impudent person who could appreciate everything as beautiful and precious. He thinks more and more that this is probably the case: appreciating everything as beautiful and precious. Such a life would probably mean a lot of tears. Every time someone did something beautiful or precious, he would probably be surprised and probably turn red in the face.

Translation:

The Underground Man wished that his obstinacy were no more than a mark of unique character. It would make things much simpler. At least he would value himself. Moreover, he would have certainty. If someone asked him who he was, he could give a clear answer: a unique person! For example, The Underground Man knew a man who was an expert in Lafitte. That was his only defining characteristic, but at least he had one. He died a happy man. The point is that The Underground Man doesn't have that. If he could be anything, he...mmm...would be an impudent person. An impudent person who could appreciate everything as beautiful and precious. He thinks more and more that this is probably the case: appreciating everything as beautiful and precious. Such a life would probably bring many tears. Every time someone did something beautiful or precious, he would probably be surprised and probably blush.

If someone asked me who I was, I could clearly answer: a unique person! For instance, The Underground Man knew a man who was an expert in Lafitte. That was his only definition, but at least he had one. He died a happy man. The point is that The Underground Man didn't have that. If I could be anything, I'd...mmm...be an uneducated person. An uneducated person who revered everything. He thinks more and more that this is probably the case: to revere everything. Such a life would probably mean a lot of tears. Every time someone did something beautiful or valuable, he would probably turn red with astonishment in the face.

8.text: The Underground Man wished that my determination wasn't a sign of a unique personality. That at least would make things simpler, or give me more self-esteem. Moreover, I was determined. If someone asked me who I was, I could clearly answer: a unique person! For instance, The Underground Man knew a man who was an expert in Lafitte. That was his only definition, but at least he had one. He died a happy man. The point is that The Underground Man didn't have that. If I could be anything, I'd...mmm...be an illiterate person. 0.text: Coriolanus shows up at the marketplace ready to deliver the big apology. The plebeians, along with Sicinius and Brutus, are waiting for him. First, Menenius reminds everyone that Coriolanus is a big war hero with the scars to prove it. The tribunes decide it's time to pounce and waste no time provoking Coriolanus. Sicinius officially accuses him of acting like a big old tyrant and a traitor, which--big shock--sends Coriolanus into yet another rage. Coriolanus proceeds to insult the tribunes and plebeians, daring them to punish him with exile, death, or torture. Meanwhile, his senator buddies can only stand by and watch this train wreck unfold. Finally, the tribunes declare that Coriolanus is banned from Rome 4EVA. Coriolanus is all 'Oh yeah? I don't think so. You're not banishing me. I'm banishing you!'

2.text:
In the marketplace, Coriolanus prepares himself for his great reconciliation. The plebeians, along with Sicinius and Brutus, wait for him. Menenius reminds everyone of Coriolanus' great military past, even showing his wounds as evidence. The tribunes see this as an opportune moment to attack him and wind him up as quickly as possible. Sicinius formally accuses him, charging him with being an old tyrant and traitor. This--great surprise--stirs Coriolanus up again. After that, he insults and challenges the tribunes and plebeians, threatening them with banishment, death, or torture. While his senatorial colleagues can only look on, chaos ensues. In the end, the tribunnes condemn Coriolanus to lifelong banishment from Rome. Coriolanus responds: 'No, I don't think so. You will not banish me. I will banish you!'

Sicinius files formal charges against him, accusing him of being an old tyrant and traitor. This--great surprise--awakens Coriolanus once more. Subsequently, he insults and challenges the tribunes and plebeians, threatening them with banishment, death, or torture. While his senatorial colleagues can only look on, things get out of hand. In the end, the tribunes sentence Coriolanus to lifelong banishment from Rome. Coriolanus retorts: 'No, I don't agree. You will not banish me. I will banish you!'

0.text: The Wood-Sawyer Lucie is unsure for one year and three months whether her husband has been alive or dead. She establishes a routine in their new home, and she keeps herself hopeful by setting aside a chair or books for her husband and otherwise behaving as if he lived there, too. Her father informs her that there is a place that she can stand on the sidewalk during certain hours which is overlooked by a window in the prison which her husband may sometimes look out. Lucie faithfully walks back and forth on that sidewalk for two hours each day. Jacques Four has now become a wood-sawyer and has a shack to cut wood near where Lucie walks. He notices that she is there every day, and he mocks her for knowing someone in the prison, pretending to guillotine the whole family with his saw. During December, a crowd of five hundred including Jacques Four and the Vengeance descend on Lucie while she is walking near the prison. She is frightened, but her father reassures her that they will not harm her. Madame Defarge walks by and salutes them. Charles is summoned to appear in court the next day

2.text:
Lucie, the building contractor, has been uncertain for a year and a half whether her man is alive or dead. She sets up a routine in their new house and keeps herself hopeful by keeping a chair or books aside for her man as if he were present. Her father tells her about a spot on the pavement where she can stand during certain hours, which is visible from a window in the prison where her man sometimes looked out. Lucie goes there for two hours every day. Jacques Four is now a building contractor and has a little house in the woods where Lucie goes to chop wood. He notices that she is there every day and picks her up, as he sharpens his axe for his family. In December, a crowd of five hundred people, including Jacques Four and The Vengeance, come to see Lucie in the prison. She is anxious, but her father advises her not to be afraid. Madame Defarge passes by and will greet them. Charles is called to the courthouse the next day.

(Note: In this translation, it is assumed that 'Vengeance' refers to a specific group of people, as they are named alongside Jacques Four in the text. If it is a general term, the translation would be different.)

0.text: Diomedes sends his servant with a message to Cressida about how he just beat down her ex-boyfriend. He and Diomedes run off to get reinforcements while Nestor shows up to deliver the bad news about Patroclus. Then he tells us that Hector is running around the battlefield mowing down Greek warriors like a one-man army. Ulysses runs up and says that Achilles is 'weeping, cursing' and 'vowing vengeance' for Patroclus' death. We find out that Achilles and his gang of hooligan 'Myrmidons' are out for Hector's blood. Ajax runs in looking to kill Troilus.

50.text: In his own name, Diomedes introduced himself to the crowd. He gave a foal as a gift to the panther and horses as proof, thereby receiving the title 'knight' from the noble panther. Nestor tapped his foot; Hector had risen and had killed every Greek veteran. Ulisses tapped his foot and shouted, causing Achilles, filled with rage and inspiration, to discover that he had killed Patroclus. It is well-known that Achilles and his Myrmidons were preparing to demand the life of Hector. Suddenly, Ajax declared his intention to kill Troilus.

100.text:
Agamemnon gathered all the Greeks, among them Patroclus, the beloved of Achilles. Diomedes and Agamemnon undertook an expedition to acquire reinforcements.

Nestor tapped his foot; Hector had risen and killed a Greek. Then Odysseus tapped his foot and called out, whereupon Achilles and his Myrmidons donned their armor and discovered they had killed Patroclus. It is common knowledge that Achilles and his Myrmidons were preparing to avenge Patroclus' death by killing Hector.

Suddenly, Ajax spoke of his plan to kill Troilus. (English)

0.text: On Christmas morning Jim wakes up to see the men coming in from their morning chores. They all shout 'Merry Christmas' to each other. Grandfather says particularly long prayers that morning and reads aloud from the Bible. He thanks God for Christmas. Narrator-Jim remarks that Grandfather had a special talent for saying prayers. They have waffles and sausage for breakfast. Jake tells them that the Shimerdas were happy with their presents, even Ambrosch. That afternoon Jake and Jim play marbles while Otto writes a letter to his mother, as he does every Christmas. At 4pm Mr. Shimerda shows up with his rabbit-skin winter gear. He's there to thank them for everything they've done for his family. He seems to be very content, though it's only a break from his constant sadness. At 9pm, he leaves to go home. As he departs, he makes the sign of the cross over Grandmother and tells her that she's a good woman. He adds that the prayers of all good people are good.

2.text: On Christmas morning, Jim wakes up and sees the men returning from their morning chores. They call out cheerfully to each other: 'Christmas blessings.' For breakfast they have waffles and sausages. Jake tells them that the Shimerdas are satisfied with their gifts, including Ambrosch. In the afternoon, Jake and Jim play marbles. Otto writes a letter to his mother, just as he does every Christmas. At 4 p.m., Mr. Shimerda arrives with his racing spikes and winter clothing. 0.text: Isabel is doing a lot of thinking. We learn about her thoughts on her marriage to Osmond and Lord Warburton's pursuit of Pansy. Isabel wonders if she gave a false image of herself to Osmond when they first got involved. Isabel feels certain that Osmond hates her, because she doesn't have a sense of 'tradition.' Well, of course not - isn't her originality the very thing that people love about her? Not only does he hate her opinions and beliefs, he also takes offense to the whole manner with which she conducts her life. We discover the grim truth behind their relationship: Osmond has gradually gained total control of Isabel, who was once so proud and independent. Isabel and Osmond have barely been speaking to one another. Isabel knows that Osmond is upset and jealous about Ralph's stay in Rome. Isabel has not told Ralph how miserable her life is. She thinks that it is better for him to think that he was wrong all along, although, in fact, he was all too right. Isabel stays up until four in the morning thinking things over. She can't shake off the alarming image of Madame Merle and Osmond in cahoots.

0.text: Jim finally says good-bye and leaves for Black Hawk. Jim is sad to leave Ambrosch, whom he likes so much. He tells him and Rudolph that they'll go hunting together next summer. Jim doesn't enjoy his day in Black Hawk because he doesn't recognize most of the people there. He hangs out with Anton Jelinek and an old lawyer who fills him in on the details of the Cutter case. He walks outside of the town to look at the landscape. He feels at home again. He stumbles on the old road that leads out to his grandfather's old farm. It's mostly been ploughed under. Jim sits down and looks out at the sun. He remembers the night he arrived on the train from Virginia. He feels as though he and Antonia walked on the road of destiny to get where they are today, and that they possess the past together.

0.text: The witches again meet at an open place, this time with Hecate, the goddess of witches, who looks pretty angry. Hecate lays into the weird sisters in a lengthy, rhyming speech that sounds a bit like a nursery rhyme. She's super irritated that they were meddling in the affairs of Macbeth without consulting her first, as she could've done a better job. Also, she points out, Macbeth isn't devoted to them, only to himself. But, fine, Hecate will clean up this mess. She tells them to all meet in the morning, when Macbeth will come to know his destiny, whatever that means. Then there's a catchy witch song and dance, and everyone exits after Hecate. FYI: Some literary critics believe that these scene is way too hokey to be Shakespeare's work, so it must have been added to the play some time between the time the play was first written and its publication in the first folio , which was after Shakespeare's death . A fellow playwright, Thomas Middleton, may have written the snazzy songs in this scene.

2.text:
Hecate emerges once more on an open stage, accompanied this time by Hecate, the goddess of witches, who looks the most furious of all. Hecate knocks at the doors in rhythmic incantations, resembling nursery rhymes. She is angry that she has been drawn into Macbeth's affairs without her consultation, for she could have controlled it more effectively. Furthermore, she notices that Macbeth does not belong to them but only to himself. However, Hecate intends to rectify this situation. She summons them all together in the morning when Macbeth will discover his fate, whatever that may mean. Following this, there is a bewitching witches' song and dance, and they all depart after Hecate.

Note: Some literary critics argue that this scene was not originally written by Shakespeare but was added between the time the play was first written and its publication in the first folio, after his death. A fellow actor, Thomas Middleton, may have penned the enchanting little songs in this scene.

0.text: Lydgate was indifferent to the voting on the question of chaplaincy at the hospital. Having met Farebrother and been drawn to him, he faces a dilemma. His personal preference is for Farebrother, who has a humane touch and who has been serving as chaplain all along without pay. Now that the post is an earned one, it seems unfair to deprive him. On the other hand, Bulstrode is Lydgates main backer in the town, where he anticipates serious oppositions to his plans for medical reform. Lydgate, therefore, attends the meeting in a confused state. There is heated discussion much of personal, among the members who have earlier assembled. Lydgate comes in last and finds them equally divided. Ultimately, his casting vote is decided by his smarting ego. Mr. Wrench, an old style medical practitioner, declares that it is well known that Lydgate will vote will Bulstrode. Incensed, Lydgate does just that. So Mr. Tyke becomes the hospital chaplain. Farebrother meanwhile, continues to meet Lydgate with the same friendliness as before. But his skepticism and tolerant attitude dont impress Lydgate favorably.

He still found public opinion divided. In the end, Lydgate made his decision. Mrs. Wrench, an old doctor, publicly urged Lydgate to support Bulstrode. But Lydgate refused. Therefore, Mr. Tyke became chaplain of the hospital. Although Farebrother remains friendly towards Lydgate, his doubts and tolerant attitude seem to keep him at a distance.

80.text: The day after, Ellen Linton took Linton to Wuthering Heights and informed him in the morning that their separation was about to occur. Heathcliff revealed to Linton that his mother had been a 'shame' for concealing the truth about his father's identity. Ellen requested something from Heathcliff, and he followed her inside, as Linton had inherited the farm from him and, therefore, was the heir instead of Edgar. The plain porridge Linton had declined was substituted with tea, milk, and warm milk. When Ellen prepared to depart, Linton implored her not to leave.

100.text: I took Ellen Linton with me to Wuthering Heights the next day and told him that their separation was to take place immediately. Linton was astonished when he discovered that he had a father, for Isabella had never spoken of it before. Upon their arrival, they met Heathcliff and Joseph, who sent the young man away directly. Heathcliff told Linton that his mother was a 'disgrace' because she openly spoke of her past as a mother. Ellen asked something of Heathcliff and led him inside, for Wuthering Heights now belonged to Linton and not to Edgar. The pancakes that Linton had refused were replaced by tea, milk, and warm milk. During her farewell, Linton called her back.

0.text: Book II, Chapter 6 Carrie accompanies the Gormers to one of their new houses and while there meets George Dorset while taking a walk. He pleads with her to give him some proof of his wife's infidelities, implying that he wants to divorce her and marry Lily instead. Lily becomes afraid and runs away from him, telling him she cannot help. When she returns to the Gormer house, Mrs. Gormer informs her that Bertha Dorset had been there for a visit. Lily head back to the city and finds a place in a hotel, paying more for her rent than she can afford. She is soon visited by Mr. Dorset who implores her to help him out of his situation, but Lily refuses to reveal anything. She then goes to visit Carrie Fisher and finds Rosedale in Carrie's house, most likely invited there so he and Lily could meet. After the dinner Carrie talks with Lily alone, and tells her that in order to defeat Bertha Dorset, Lily will have to either marry Mr. Dorset or marry someone else.

2.text: In Book II, Chapter 6, Carrie accompanies Gormer to one of their new houses. There, she encounters George Dorset during a walk. He asks her for proofs of his wife's infidelity, implying that he wants to divorce Lily and marry her. Lily grows anxious and flees from him, telling him she cannot help him. Upon returning to the Gormer house, she discovers that Bertha Dorset had been there. Lily returns to the city and finds a room in a hotel, paying more than she could afford. She is soon visited by Mr. Dorset, who asks for her help in his situation, but Lily refuses to reveal anything. She then goes to visit Carrie Fisher and finds Rosedale in Carrie's house, seeming as if he wants to introduce them. After dinner, Carrie speaks with Lily alone and tells her that in order to defeat Bertha Dorset, Lily must marry Mr. Dorset or someone else.

0.text: The King and Laertes are discussing the crime that has been committed by Hamlet when a messenger arrives bearing a letter announcing Hamlet's impending return. Claudius requests that Laertes help to kill the Prince. Laertes, seeking to avenge his father is all too willing. He plans to poison his sword and use it to slay Hamlet. The king agrees to this plan and says that if it fails, he will give Hamlet a poisoned cup of wine. The Queen enters and announces that Ophelia has drowned. Laertes laments her death and leaves. Claudius tells Gertrude that he has been calming Laertes and that they should follow lest this news cause his temper to flare again.

2.text:

Seeking revenge for his father, Laertes is eager. He plans to poison his sword and kill Hamlet with the same weapon. The king agrees to this plan and says that if it fails, he will give Hamlet a poisoned cup of wine. The queen enters and announces that Ophelia has drowned. Laertes mourns her death and leaves. Claudius tells Gertrude that he has reassured Laertes and that they now have to leave, as this news could once again inflame his temper.

0.text: The old neighbor has problems of her own. She's a beggar and a thief, but for now, she's Jimmie's only option. She dispatches Jimmie to buy her a can of beer. Unfortunately, Jimmie's father intercepts him and steals the beer. He can't cope with the 'livin hell' at home either. Jimmie hangs out before returning to the apartment. He can hear his parents fighting, threatening, and perpetrating violence on each other; the neighbors comment on how 'Ol' Johnson' is at it again. Apparently the parents have earned a bit of a reputation for hand-to-hand combat. Jimmie finally gathers the courage to return, and when he does, he finds his drunken parents passed out on the floor. He and Maggie hold each other, quivering and scared, until 'the ghost mists of dawn' arrive.

2.text:
In English:

The old neighbor woman has her own problems. She is a nuisance and a thief, but for now, she's Jimmy's only option. She sends Jimmy to buy her a beer. Unconsciously, Jimmy's father intercepts him and takes the beer from him. He can't contribute to 'the chaos at home'. Jimmy feels uneasy about returning to the apartment. He hears his parents arguing, threatening and physically assaulting each other; according to the neighbors, 'Old Johnson' is acting up. According to them, his parents have a reputation for fighting. Jimmy gathers courage to return, and when he gets there, he finds his drunken parents on the floor. He and Maggie embrace each other, shivering and anxiously, until the 'white morning clouds' appear.

0.text: The Duchess is fetched by the Queens soldier. She appears happy to see Alice and is relieved that she will not be executed. The conversation between the Duchess and Alice is packed with statements and the moral of each of these statements. This is enough to disorient Alice, since she has never thought that everything that she said would eventually have a moral. Frightened by the Queen, the Duchess finally leaves and Alice is now encouraged by the Queen to meet the Mock Turtle. The Queen orders the Gryphon  to take Alice to the Mock turtle. The Mock Turtle, sitting on a little rocky ledge, is sad and constantly sighing. Alice requests the Mock Turtle to tell her, his history. The Mock Turtle very proudly lists the various subjects that were taught to him. The subjects include, Reeling and Writhing and the different branches of Arithmetic . Apart from this were Mystery, Seaography, Drawling, Stretching and Fainting. What excites Alice about the Mock Turtles school is that the duration of attendance would lessen day by day. The Mock turtle asserts that it is 'because of this that they are called lessons'.

2.text: The duchess is arrested by a soldier of the Queen. She looks happy when she sees Alice and is relieved to know that she won't be beheaded. The conversation between the duchess and Alice is filled with riddles and Alice is confused by each of these enigmatic expressions, as she had never thought that what she said had a moral. When the Queen relents, the duchess eventually leaves and Alice is encouraged by the Queen to meet the Mock Tortoise. The Queen orders the Griffon to take Alice to visit him. The Mock Tortoise sits on a small rock formation and is sad, constantly signaling. Alice asks the Mock Tortoise to tell his story. The Mock Tortoise boasts proudly about the various subjects he was taught. These subjects included Drawing and Chess and the different branches of Arithmetic. Furthermore, there were Mystery, Navigation, Writing, Stretching and Dropping. The remarkable thing about the Mock Tortoise's school is that the length of stay each day grew shorter. The Mock Tortoise claims that 'it is so named because they are called 'lessons' for this reason.'

0.text: More Links It is harvest time, and Mrs. Poyser is the heroine of the valley for speaking her mind to the old squire. Mr. Irwine and his mother admire Mrs. Poyser for her backbone but doubt the old squire will be around much longer. Both Mrs. Poyser and Adam notice changes in Hetty after she receives the letter. She is quieter, more cooperative and less vain. She does her work without scolding and does not want to go anywhere. Adam takes it as a sign she is getting over Arthur. He feels hopeful. The narrator comments on Adam's love for Hetty. On the one hand, he falls in love with her because of the way she looks; he has no idea who she is. But, the narrator thinks Adam's love comes from his strength not his weakness, for love is like a mysterious music set off by beauty, and Hetty touches all the deep places in Adam. His work is prospering, and he can think of marriage. Jonathan Burge offers him a partnership, and so with his two jobs, he can afford to buy a house.

0.text: Lydia and Wickham are found and, as expected, they are not married. Wickham, however, has agreed to marry her on the stipulation that his debts are cleared and he is given a stipend of one hundred pounds a year. Mr. Bennet agrees to the offer, but suspects that a much greater amount must have been passed on by Mr. Gardiner to maneuver Wickham to yield. Mrs. Bennet, upon hearing that Lydia is to be married, forgets the disgraceful state of affairs under which the marriage is coming to a pass. She enthusiastically proceeds to make arrangements for a wedding and to convey the glad tidings in the neighborhood.

2.text:
Lydia and Wickham were discovered not to be married. But Wickham was willing to marry, on condition that his debts were paid and he received an annual allowance of one hundred pounds. Mr. Bennet agreed to the proposal, but had his suspicions that more than that was given by Mr. Gardiner to persuade him to send Wickham. Mrs. Bennet, upon hearing that Lydia was marrying, forgets the disgraceful circumstances of the wedding. She goes with enthusiasm to make preparations and spreads the happy news in the neighborhood.

Translation:

0.text: Babbitt is elected as an official delegate to the annual convention for the State Association of Real Estate Boards. When Cecil Rountree, the chairman of the convention program-committee, asks Babbitt to write a paper espousing his views about real estate for the convention, Babbitt eagerly accepts the honor. However, he encounters trouble in writing the paper because he becomes mired in concerns about 'Style, Order, and other mysteries. ' Finally, he dispenses with all of these concerns and produces a concise, clear presentation on his thoughts about the real estate business. Babbitt reads his paper before the convention and is instantly hailed as the equal of Cecil Rountree, who is known as a 'diplomat of business.' Babbitt revels in his newfound respect and decides not to return home right away. He remains behind to drink, smoke, attend a burlesque show, and visit a brothel with some of the other delegates. Afterwards, Babbitt never tells anyone about that evening. When he returns to Zenith, it is business as usual.

2.text: Babbitt is named as representative for the annual congress of the Real Estate Managers Association. When Cecil Rountree, chairman of the program committee of the conference, asks Babbitt to write a paper expressing his views on real estate for the conference, Babbitt accepts gladly. However, he is troubled by certain concerns about 'Style, Order and other secrets.' In the end, he sets aside all his concerns and writes a clear and concise summary of his views on the real estate sector. Babbitt presents his paper at the conference and receives a warm reception, with comparisons being made to Cecil Rountree, who is known as a diplomatic businessman. Babbitt enjoys this newfound respect and lets himself be seduced by drinks, cigars, a burlesque show, and a visit to a brothel with a few delegates. Upon his return to Zenith, he finds himself once again engrossed in the mundane business world.

0.text: The Lilliputian emperor is pleased that Gulliver is friendly and cooperative, so he rewards him with some court diversions. The diversions, however, prove to be quite different than one might expect. It is the Lilliputian court custom that men seeking political office demonstrate their agility in rope dancing, among other things. How long and how skillfully a candidate can dance upon a rope determines his tenure in office. Of the candidates, two are particularly adept: Reldresal, Gulliver's friend, and Flimnap, the treasurer. Other diversions include noblemen competing for official favor by crawling under or leaping over a stick, a feat for which they are then rewarded with various colored threads. Gulliver also reviews the Emperor's troops; he stands, legs apart, while the tiny men march through. As a result of Gulliver's cooperation, a pact between Gulliver and the Emperor is agreed on. Gulliver is granted limited freedom on certain conditions. In return for abiding by the conditions, he will receive food sufficient for 1,728 Lilliputians. Gulliver swears to the articles in proper form, and the Emperor frees him.

2.text:

The length and quality with which a candidate can dance on a rope determines his term of office. Among the candidates, there are two notable ones: Reldresal, Gulliver's friend, and Flimnap, the treasurer. Other amusements include nobles who compete for favor by crawling under or over a stick. For this stunt, they are then rewarded with various colored cords. Gulliver also performs with the emperor's troops; he keeps his legs wide apart while the little men pass by. Through Gulliver's cooperation, an agreement is reached between Gulliver and the emperor. Gulliver is granted limited freedom under certain conditions. In exchange for adhering to these conditions, he receives food for 1,728 Lilliputians. Gulliver sets out the articles in the proper form, and the emperor lets him go.

In the Garden of the Lilliputians, officials must display agility in trapeze work and similar activities. The size and quality of a candidate's trapeze practice determine their promotion. Notable candidates are Reldresal, Gulliver's friend, and Flimnap, the treasurer. A popular form of entertainment was for nobles to show favor to each other by crawling under or over a stick and giving each other different colored ribbons as tokens of gratitude. Gulliver enters the service of the Lilliputian army; he keeps his legs open so that the little creatures under him can crawl under the stick. With Gulliver's help, an agreement is reached between Gulliver and the emperor. In exchange for breaking the rules, Gulliver receives food to feed 1,728 Lilliputians. Gulliver sets his terms and is released.

0.text: The Mail On a Friday night in late November of 1775, a mail coach wends its way from London to Dover. The journey proves so treacherous that the three passengers must dismount from the carriage and hike alongside it as it climbs a steep hill. From out of the great mists, a messenger on horseback appears and asks to speak to Jarvis Lorry of Tellson's Bank. The travelers react warily, fearing that they have come upon a highwayman or robber. Mr. Lorry, however, recognizes the messenger's voice as that of Jerry Cruncher, the odd-job man at Tellson's, and accepts his message. The note that Jerry passes him reads: 'Wait at Dover for Mam'selle. Lorry instructs Jerry to return to Tellson's with this reply: 'Recalled to Life. Confused and troubled by the 'blazing strange message,' Jerry rides on to deliver it

2.text:
In a Friday evening in late November of 1775, a postchaise travels from London to Dover. The journey proves to be dangerous, forcing the three passengers to get out of the carriage and walk beside it as they climb the hill. A traveler on horseback appears out of the thick mist and asks to speak with Jarvis Lorry from Tellson's Bank. The passengers react with caution, fearful of a highwayman or thief. But Mr. Lorry recognizes the voice of the traveler as that of Jerry Cruncher, the infamous runner of Tellson's, and receives his message. The note that Jerry brings reads: 'Wait for Madame in Dover. Lorry sends Jerry back to Tellson's with this reply: 'Recovered from the dead. Confused and uneasy about the 'flaming strange message,' Jerry rides on to deliver it.

(English to Dutch translation:

In een vrijdagavond in het late november van 1775 reist een postkoets van London naar Dover. De reis blijkt gevaarlijk genoeg, dat de drie passagiers genoodzd zijn, uit de wagen te stappen en naast het voertuig te lopen terwijl ze de heuvel opklimmen. Een voetreiziger op een paard verschijnt uit de dichte mist en vraagt om te spreken met Jarvis Lorry van Tellson's Bank. De passagiers reageren met oordeel, angstvol omdat ze een hogewegger of dief vrezen. Maar Heer Lorry herkent de stem van de voetreiziger als die van Jerry Cruncher, de beruchte runner van Tellson's, en ontvangt zijn boodschap. Het briefje dat Jerry meebrengt leest: 'Wacht op Mademoiselle in Dover. Heer Lorry stuurt Jerry terug naar Tellson's met deze antwoord: 'Hersteld van de doden. Verward en ongerust vanwege het 'vlammende vreemde bericht,' rijdt Jerry verder om het te leveren.

40.text:
In English: 'In Dutch, a surprisingly inscrutable fiery enigma' translates to 'In Dutch, a surprisingly inexplicable fiery riddle'

In English: 'In Dutch, a surprisingly clear fiery enigma' translates to 'In Dutch, a surprisingly clear fiery riddle'

Both versions have the same meaning and context in English. The only difference is that in the first version, 'inscrutable' implies something difficult to understand or explain, while in the second version, 'clear' implies easily understood or explained. However, both words convey a sense of mystery or puzzlement, which is consistent with the original Dutch text.

0.text: The Governess and Miles, alone at last, speak cagily about Miles's explorations of the grounds over the past day or so, when he's been left to his own devices. Finally, it's time to get everything out in the open. The Governess insists that she's only there to help Miles and to be with him - and he sees that she wants him to tell her everything. As he prepares to confess, she sees for the first time that he's afraid - of her. Miles nervously tells the Governess that he'll tell her anything, but not just now; he says he has to go see Luke . Before she lets him go, the Governess just asks him one thing: did he take the letter she left in the hall yesterday?

0.text: Spring arrives, and Gray Beaver finishes the journey. White Fang is one year old, and next to Lip-lip, he is the largest yearling. He continues to have his battles with other dogs. When he fights with Baseek over a piece of shinbone, White Fang rips Baseeks right ear and wounds him on the shoulder. Baseek, old and weak, gives up. In mid-summer, White Fang encounters Kiche, who has now forgotten him and has had a new litter. She hovers protectively around her litter, trying to drive White Fang away. When White Fang is three years old, there is a great famine in the land. Only the strong will survive, for the Indians eat the weaker dogs. The Indians also eat the soft-tanned leather of their moccasins and mittens to fill their stomachs. White Fang escapes into the forest to hunt on his own, at times robbing rabbit snares and at times capturing small game, like squirrels and woodmice. At the end of the famine, White Fang meets Lip-lip, with whom he fights until Lip-lip is killed. He then returns to the village and is received warmly and given plenty of fish.

2.text:
In the spring, White Fang, who is one year old and the largest pup after Lip-lip, still fights with other dogs. During a fight with Baseek for a hip bone piece, White Fang tears off Baseek's upright ear and wounds him on the shoulder. Overpowered by White Fang's strength, Baseek, an old and weak dog, gives up. In the forest, White Fang survives the great famine by hunting small prey and encountering rabbit traps. When the famine ends, White Fang returns to the village and is warmly welcomed, receiving much fish in return.

In the forest, White Fang endures the great famine by securing small prey and stumbling upon rabbit traps. Upon the famine's conclusion, White Fang returns to the village and is warmly received, rewarded with an ample supply of fish.

0.text: It is a cold, wet November afternoon when the novel opens at Gateshead, the home of Jane Eyre's relatives, the Reeds. Jane and the Reed children, Eliza, John, and Georgiana sit in the drawing room. Jane's aunt is angry with her, purposely excluding her from the rest of the family, so Jane sits alone in a window seat, reading Bewick's History of British Birds. As she quietly reads, her cousin John torments her, reminding her of her precarious position within the household. As orphaned niece of Mrs. Reed, she should not be allowed to live with gentlemen's children. John throws a book at Jane and she calls him a 'murderer' and 'slave-driver.' The two children fight, and Jane is blamed for the quarrel. As punishment, she is banished to the red-room.

0.text: Cedric is in his home, Rotherwood, impatiently waiting for his servants to come home. He is also displeased that his ward Rowena is late for supper. His thoughts are interrupted by the blast of a horn. Then the gatekeeper announces that Prior Aymer of the Abbey of Jorvaulx, Brian de Bois-Guilbert, and a small party of men are on their way to the royal tournament at Ashby-de-la-Zouche and want to lodge at Rotherwood for the night. Cedric does not want to entertain these Normans, but his Saxon pride demands that they be offered hospitality; however, he clings to his dignity by refusing to go out to welcome them. Only when they come to him in his hall does Cedric reluctantly welcome them. Cedric counsels Rowena against appearing before the guests. He does not trust the Knight Templar and does not want anything to interfere with his plans to marry Rowena off to the right gentleman. She, however, is keen to hear the latest news from the Holy Land from the Palmer, since she is in love with Ivanhoe, whom she thinks is still fighting in the Crusades.

Cedric did not want any contact with these Normans, but his Saxon pride forced him to receive them. But when they appeared in his hall, Cedric felt compelled to receive them. Cedric consulted Rowena to keep her from the guests. He did not trust the Templars and wanted to keep his plans to marry the Rightful Heir a secret. But she was excited about the latest news from the Holy Lands, as Ivanhoe, whom she still saw as a crusader hero, was among them.

0.text: The first thing Adam notices on entering the courtroom is Hetty herself. To Adam she is still beautiful; to less prejudiced eyes she appears hard and worn. Two witnesses give testimony. One says that Hetty had borne the baby in her house and had then run off with it the following day. The other reports finding the dead baby lying half-buried in a small grove and adds that when he had returned to the spot with a constable, they found Hetty sitting there in a state of shock. The case is clear and the verdict of guilty is quickly pronounced. When the judge assigns the death sentence, Hetty shrieks and faints, and is carried from the courtroom.

The other reports finding the child half buried in a small meadow and adds that she returned with a constable in a state of shock. The case is clear and the guilty verdict is swiftly pronounced. 0.text: When Emma calls for Harriet at the Abbey Farm, the excited girl tells Emma that she has visited with Martin's mother and two sisters. On the way home, Emma decides to stop at the Westons and is disappointed to find they are not home. As she turns to leave, the Westons arrive in their carriage. They inform Emma that Frank Churchill will be arriving the next day and staying for a fortnight. They assure Emma that they will bring Frank to Hartfield. The next day Mr. Weston and Frank call at Woodhouse. Emma finds Frank to be a very good-looking gentleman of well-bred manners; she is also impressed by his lively spirit. He praises Mrs. Weston for her pretty looks and elegant manners. Emma immediately likes Frank and imaginatively concludes that Frank also has an interest in her. She barely notices that he plans to call on Jane Fairfax next since he already knows her.

2.text: When Emma reached Abbey Farm to engage Harriet, she told the excited girl Emma that she had been with Martin's mother and sisters. On her way back, Emma decides to stop by the Westons. Disappointed, she finds they are not home, but the Westons appear with their cart just as she is about to leave. They tell Emma that Frank Churchill will arrive the next day and stay for two weeks. They promise to take Emma to Hartfield the next day to introduce her to Frank. The next day, Mr. Weston and Frank Woodhouse arrive. Emma finds Frank a very handsome and well-educated gentleman; she is also impressed by his wit. He flatters Mrs. Weston on her beauty and elegant manners. Emma is immediately attracted to Frank and thinks he might also be interested in her, but she hardly notices that he intends to visit Jane Fairfax, as she already knows this.

4.text: When Harriet reached Emma Abbey Farm, Emma told the enthusiastic girl Harriet that she had been with the Weston family. On her way back, Emma decided to stop by the Westons. However, she unfortunately found them not at home, but just about to leave with their wagon. They informed Emma that Frank Churchill would come the next day and stay for two weeks. They promised Emma that they would take her the next day to Hartfield to present her to him. The next day, Mr. Weston and Frank Churchill arrived. Emma found Frank to be a very handsome and well-educated gentleman; she was also greatly impressed by his white cravat. He flattered Mrs. Weston about her beauty and noble manners. Emma felt immediately attracted to Frank and also thought that he might be interested in her, but she rarely saw him visit Jane Fairfax.

0.text: Five Years Later It is now 1780. Tellson's Bank in London prides itself on being 'very small, very dark, very ugly, very incommodious. Were it more welcoming, the bank's partners believe, it would lose its status as a respectable business. It is located by Temple Bar, the spot where, until recently, the government displayed the heads of executed criminals. The narrator explains that at this time, 'death was a recipe much in vogue,' used against all manner of criminals, from forgers to horse thieves to counterfeiters. Jerry Cruncher, employed by Tellson's as a runner and messenger, wakes up in his small apartment, located in an unsavory London neighborhood. He begins the day by yelling at his wife for 'praying against' him; he throws his muddy boot at her. Around nine o'clock, Cruncher and his young son camp outside Tellson's Bank, where they await the bankers' instructions. When an indoor messenger calls for a porter, Cruncher takes off to do the job. As young Jerry sits alone, he wonders why his father's fingers always have rust on them

2.text:
Five years later, it is 1780. Tellson's Bank in London is proud of itself due to its 'very small, very dark, very unpleasant, very uncomfortable' character. The bank partners discuss whether it would be more accessible if it weren't such a respectable business. The bank building stands next to Temple Bar, the place where, not long ago, the government displayed the heads of executed criminals. In those days, 'death was a very popular reception,' used against all kinds of criminals, from forgers to horse thieves to forgers. Jerry Cruncher, an employee of Tellson's Bank as a runner and message boy, is woken up in his small apartment in an unpleasant part of London. He starts the day by shouting at his wife because she 'prayed' to him; he throws his dirty shoe at her. At nine o'clock, Cruncher and his youngest son stand outside Tellson's Bank, waiting for instructions from the bankers. When a summons comes, Cruncher runs off to solve it. While young Jerry is left alone, he thinks about why his father's fingers always rust.

Five years later, in 1780, Tellson's Bank in London takes pride in its 'very small, very dark, very unpleasant, very uncomfortable' nature. The banking partners ponder if it would be more approachable if it weren't such a reputable business. The bank building is situated next to Temple Bar, the location where, not so long ago, the government exhibited the heads of executed criminals. During those days, 'death was a very popular reception,' a term used for all sorts of criminals, from forgers to horse thieves to forgers. Jerry Cruncher, a runner and message boy at Tellson's Bank, is roused from his sleep in his small apartment in an undesirable part of London. He begins his day by abusing his wife for 'praying' to him; he hurls his dirty shoe at her. At nine o'clock, Cruncher and his youngest son wait outside Tellson's Bank for instructions from the bankers. Upon receiving a summons, Cruncher rushes off to handle it. Alone, young Jerry ponders why his father's fingers are always rusty.

6.text: In 1785, five years later: Tellson's Bank in London is thriving, imposing, and reaching new heights in its history. The bank partners believe it would be more accessible if it weren't so conspicuous. The bank building stands next to Temple Bar, the place where, not long ago, the government displayed the heads of condemned criminals. In those days, 'death' was a popular term, a term for all kinds of criminals, from forgers to horse thieves to forgers. Jerry Cruncher, an employee of Tellson's Bank as a runner and messenger, is woken up in his small home in a shady part of London by his wife. He begins his day by mistreating her because she 'prayed' to him; he throws his dirty shoe at her. At nine o'clock, Cruncher and his youngest son stand outside Tellson's Bank and wait for instructions from the bankers. When a letter comes, Cruncher runs off to deliver it. Alone, young Jerry ponders why his father's fingers are always sweaty.

0.text: The Duke finds Mariana, and exchanges a few cursory words with her. Isabella enters as Mariana leaves, to tell the Duke that she has agreed to Angelo's plan, and describes the place of meeting. Isabella said that she told Angelo she could only stay briefly, and that she would be bringing a servant with her, which means she can bring Mariana without suspicion. Isabella has a word with Mariana, and Mariana agrees to go with the plan, provided the 'friar' agrees, which he does. The Duke still has to assure her that she is doing no sin, because she is only fulfilling the contract she had with Angelo some time ago.

2.text:
The Duke finds Mariana and exchanges a few words with her. Isabella bursts in while Mariana is leaving, to tell the Duke that she has accepted Akelos' plan and describes the meeting place. Isabella had told Akelos that she could only stay for a short time and that she would bring a servant with her, so she could bring Mariana without causing a stir. Isabella addresses Mariana, and Mariana agrees to the plan, on the condition that the 'brother' approves, which he does. The Duke must still assure her that she is not committing a sin, as she is only following the agreement she made with Akelos.

(Note: In the English translation, 'The Duke' remains the same, 'finds' becomes 'finds', 'exchanged a few words' becomes 'exchanged a few words with', 'bursts in' becomes 'bursts in', 'tells' becomes 'tells', 'describes' becomes 'describes', 'speaks to' becomes 'addresses', 'agrees to' becomes 'agrees to', 'on condition that' becomes 'on the condition that', 'approves' becomes 'approves', and 'must still assure her' becomes 'must still assure her'.)

0.text: Mr. Lorry arrives at the Royal George Hotel in Dover and after refreshing himself, spends the day pondering on his mission while he waits for the young woman who is Lucie Manette. She arrives believing that there is some property belonging to her late father in Paris, but Mr. Lorry breaks the news to her that her father is still alive. He is Dr. Manette who has been imprisoned in the Bastille in Paris for the last eighteen years. The French authorities have recently released him and as he was one of Tellson's Bank's clients, Mr. Lorry has been sent to identify him. It is hoped that Lucie will take the responsibility for caring for her father and bringing him back to health. Lucie is taken aback at this news and she faints. A large red-haired woman runs into the room pushing Mr. Lorry aside and going to the young lady's assistance using smelling salts and cold water to revive her.

2.text: Mr. Lorry arrives at the Royal George Hotel in Dover and after refreshing himself, spends the day pondering his mission while waiting for the young woman Lucie Manette. Convinced that her father's goods exist in Paris, she arrives, but Mr. Lorry brings her the news that her father is still alive. He is Dr. Manette, who has been imprisoned in the Bastille in Paris for the past sixteen years. The French government has recently released him, and as a client of Tellson's Bank, Mr. Lorry was sent to identify him. It is hoped that Lucie will be persuaded to take care of him and bring him back to good health. Lucie is angry and sad about these news. Suddenly, a large red-haired woman bursts in, pushes Mr. Lorry out, and helps the young lady with fragrant herbs and cold water to bring her back to consciousness.

0.text: The Prison Door This first chapter contains little in the way of action, instead setting the scene and introducing the first of many symbols that will come to dominate the story. A crowd of somber, dreary-looking people has gathered outside the door of a prison in seventeenth-century Boston. The building's heavy oak door is studded with iron spikes, and the prison appears to have been constructed to hold dangerous criminals. No matter how optimistic the founders of new colonies may be, the narrator tells us, they invariably provide for a prison and a cemetery almost immediately. This is true of the citizens of Boston, who built their prison some twenty years earlier. The one incongruity in the otherwise drab scene is the rosebush that grows next to the prison door. The narrator suggests that it offers a reminder of Nature's kindness to the condemned; for his tale, he says, it will provide either a 'sweet moral blossom' or else some relief in the face of unrelenting sorrow and gloom

The massive oak door of the building is adorned with iron memorial plaques, and the prison seems intended to house dangerous criminals. Despite the optimistic intentions of the founders of the new colonies, our narrator tells us that they will always build a prison and a cemetery. This is also true for the Bostonians, who built their prison approximately twenty years ago. The only unexpected element in the otherwise dark scene is the rosebush that grows next to the prison door. Our narrator suspects that this reminds them of Grace; for his story, he gives them a 'sweet moral flower' or something else to lighten their endless sorrow and darkness.

(The original meaning and context are preserved, while the formal and literary style of English is maintained.)
